dialogues.speaker: MOVING IN ON BATES, LOUISIANA
dialogues.text: The edge of the sun at the horizon. The city glistens in the midst of the lush farmland and the brown meandering Mississippi. The SOUND OF TWO PEOPLE MAKING LOVE, OVER.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The squalor of black Bates. Trash. Lowriders. Graffiti. Vacant lots. Boarded-up buildings. Sleazy bars. The broken beer bottles in that street alone pick up the ligh of dawn. Other than that, sleeping cats and deep shadows. The people making love are getting it together. QUICKENIN BREATHING. An urgency.

dialogues.speaker: COME IN ON WINDOW
dialogues.text: in the three-room, clapboard house with a For Sale sign i front. The paint is peeling, some windows broken, the curtains limp, the whole house sags to the north, but it' no worse than all the other houses in the area. The BREATHING is PUNCTUATED with LITTLE GASPS OF PLEASURE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The interior walls have been removed, except for the bath room it is one large space, oddly livable and nice, amid poverty. The furniture is Goodwill reject. Fair Housing picket sign. Law books. A jockstrap. Monet's water lilies tacked to the stained wallpaper. An old typewriter Stacks of yellow paper, full of typing and legal pads full of handwriting. Bowl:of dried Chinese vegetables, different gauge pasta and dried flowers. A sink corroded through, with a wrench for a faucet and a bucket to catch the leaks. An Air Force exercise chart. A flourishing philodendron. The BREATHING is FASTER. WHIMPERS and SIGHS and FANFARE.

dialogues.speaker: ON BED
dialogues.text: They fall apart, happy. JACK is a thin man with a beard. ANGELA is an NYU law school graduate and a vivid beauty. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: ANGELA
dialogues.text: How do you feel?

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Saved. She laughs, snuggles closer.

dialogues.speaker: ANGELA
dialogues.text: Your beard is manifestation of a death wish, Jack, did you know that?

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Sheeit.

dialogues.speaker: ANGELA
dialogues.text: Bates considers beards a brand of communism.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Why do you carry on like it was a ten, if it wasn't ten?

dialogues.speaker: ANGELA
dialogues.text: Bates owns the town. It's asking for failure. Up on his elbow, irritated.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Now wait a second. I don't have to suck up to that anybody. I've got a publisher. She caresses his beard, deaf.

dialogues.speaker: ANGELA
dialogues.text: Shave it off. Take some menial job. You haven't worked in so long you've forgotten how.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Writing a book isn't working?

dialogues.speaker: ANGELA
dialogues.text: It would be healthy. He looks at her owlishly.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: I'm unhealthy? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: ANGELA
dialogues.text: There's a direct correlation between unemployment and sexual malfunctioning.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Was it a nine?

dialogues.speaker: ANGELA
dialogues.text: We used up the publishers' advance six months ago.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Eight?

dialogues.speaker: ANGELA
dialogues.text: We've got to come up with two grand by the end of the month or we lose the house, Jack. Jack remembers suddenly -- goes rigid -- grabs his watch.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Oh, Jesus. I'm having breakfast with the Bank in twenty minutes. Leaps out of bed, stops mid air:

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: (continuing) Seven?

dialogues.speaker: ANGELA
dialogues.text: (grins, grudgingly) And a half. He leaps back on top of her.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: You are so full of bullshit, woman...

dialogues.speaker: VERY TIGHT
dialogues.text: He looks at her, vibrant with admiration, stunned at his good luck.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Let's get married. She hugs him, abruptly as soft as she was fierce. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: ANGELA
dialogues.text: What're you gonna tell the Bank?

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: (stroking her hair, comforting her) Couple of jokes. It'll be all right. Bankers have a sense of humor too. (looks into her eyes) If I get an extension of credit, can we get married? Long look.

dialogues.speaker: ANGELA
dialogues.text: Yep. He hoots with triumph, sweeps her into his arms.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wide, bleak and untended, full of dust and broken promise Beat-up pickups. Old cars on blocks in front yards. Though it is still early, there are people leaning on por rails, on cars, hanging out, going nowhere. Jack eases hi old ten speed out of the house. CREDITS.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: swings up onto his bike and starts down the street, avoid the potholes and glass and stray dogs. The kids and neighbors wave greetings. He waves back, settling a green backpack on his shoulders, riding on, without hands. Whistling.

dialogues.speaker: DOWNTOWN
dialogues.text: Mostly boarded up empty store fronts. Many businesses wit "Bates" in the title. The newspaper building, the Dixie Daily (A Division of Bates Enterprises), is still in operation, on the main square. The square itself sports a larger than life statue of Bates in stone. Jack breezes by on his bike, whistling, tosses the statue the finger.  10 ‘all 12 13

dialogues.speaker: STORE
dialogues.text: Jack rides through the shadows of early morning still lon from the old fashioned three-story midtown Bates Departme Store.

dialogues.speaker: BATES ENTERPRISES BUILDING
dialogues.text: The tallest, newest, most imposing building in town. In front of which is a free standing sign with "Employment Opportunities" listed under the Bates motto: "Welfare Corrupts." Jack breezes by on his bike.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack rides his bike up a gangplank, hops off. La Noisette Rose is a restaurant on a paddle wheeler, on the Mississippi. Open 24 Hours. Chicken Fried Steak our Specialty! CREDITS END.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An air of superiority. Views of refineries and muddy rive out the windows. Pink tableclothes, waiters in pink jackets. A small bowl of pink walnuts on each table. Most of the customers are middle-aged, florid-faced men in business suits breakfasting with young blondes in form fitting jeans, satin blouses with tooled cowboy boots and the Farah Fawcett hairdos. Jack Brown is finishing breakfast with a sour looking BANKER in a three-piece pin striped suit. There is an awkward silence. Jack sets down his coffee cup with a clatter.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Sorry. (smiles ingratiatingly) Know why Dolly Parton's feet are so small?

dialogues.speaker: BANKER
dialogues.text: I've heard it. Jack clears his throat, regroups.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Heard about the Polish mosquito? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An 13

dialogues.speaker: BANKER
dialogues.text: Jack, if you don't get a job --

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: (to passing waiter) Check please.

dialogues.speaker: WAITER
dialogues.text: Right away, Mussier.

dialogues.speaker: BANKER
dialogues.text: Are you listening?

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Ever seen a walnut cracked by a judo chop?

dialogues.speaker: BANKER
dialogues.text: This is important. This is bottom line --

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: (taking a walnut, shoving his sleeves up) This is spectacular.

dialogues.speaker: BANKER
dialogues.text: (tight rage) Jack, you need a paying job by the end of the week. Or we'll repossess everything you own, starting with your goddam typewriter. CHOP. The pitcher of cream jumps off the table into the Banker's lap. He stands, white liquid spread over his pants front.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: It's just half and half. It'll wash out -- He grabs his napkin, wipes the man's front making it wors

dialogues.speaker: BANKER
dialogues.text: This is a new suit.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: I'll pay for the cleaning. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: BANKER
dialogues.text: With what?

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Just send the bill to the house. The Waiter comes with the check on a little tray. Jack slips his credit card into the tray. The Waiter starts away. The Banker tackles him, snatches the credit card back.

dialogues.speaker: BANKER
dialogues.text: You can't use this.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: The bank won't cash my check.

dialogues.speaker: BANKER
dialogues.text: Of course not. You're overdrawn.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: (sotto voce) They don't know that here.

dialogues.speaker: BANKER
dialogues.text: But the bank will have to honor this.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Exactly.

dialogues.speaker: BANKER
dialogues.text: But I just told you. We aren't extending your credit unless you get a job. (digs for his wallet) I'll pay. Here. How much is it? The Banker takes the bill off the tray, red-faced with anger. The Waiter sticks a toothpick in his teeth and eyeballs the ceiling. Jack takes the bill back.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: I can't allow you to do that. I invited you. You're my guest. I -- The Banker grabs it back, Jack grabs it back, knocks over the whole table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack is on his bike, circling the Employment Opportunitie sign. Stewing, pondering and circling.  15 16 17

dialogues.speaker: ON SIGN
dialogues.text: Petroleum Engineer, Computer Programmer, Accountant, etc. And at the very bottom: Cleaning Woman (Part time).

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elegant people coming and going through the polished bron and glass revolving doors. Jack swings off his bike, begins to lock it to the Loadin Zone standard in front of the front door. Next to a parked Chrysler limousine. FANCY BATES, a very chic, very voluptuous creature of about twenty-five, sweeps out of the building, wearing a full length mink coat, heads for the limo. Behind her, wringing his hands is GEFFRAN, a balding, blue-suite nervous man. Behind him, BARKLEY, the chauffeur. Jack grins, moves his bike out of her way, opens the door of the car for her. She smiles at him regally.

dialogues.speaker: FANCY
dialogues.text: Why, I do thank you so very much.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: My pleasure, foxy lady. Barkley shuts the door with care.

dialogues.speaker: ON GEFFRAN AND JACK
dialogues.text: Geffran mops his forehead, glancing sideways at Jack and his lascivious grin.

dialogues.speaker: GEFFRAN
dialogues.text: Not for you, pal.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: It's a free country.

dialogues.speaker: GEFFRAN
dialogues.text: That's Fancy Bates.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: His daughter?

dialogues.speaker: GEFFRAN
dialogues.text: Wife. Numero three. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: No shit. Think she's ready for the black experience? Geffran winces. Laughing, Jack swings in the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Poster for the Bates Credit Union, sign up sheets for baseball teams. This is the employment office for Bates Enterprises. A couple of ancient black women are waiting. A couple of computer programmers. One engineer. The tweedy SECRETARY, Wellsley, looks disapprovingly at Jack who is sitting with the women, his bookbag between his knees. He smiles back at her. The Secretary looks at her list.

dialogues.speaker: SECRETARY
dialogues.text: Miss Jackie Brown. Jack gets up, smiles at the Secretary, heads for the door

dialogues.speaker: SECRETARY
dialogues.text: (continuing) Wait. Not you. We need a part- time woman.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: (lisping) I can be a part-time woman. Wiggles into the office before she can stop him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SIDNEY MOREHOUSE, the soul of propriety, is looking over the resume and clippings and articles in Jack's bookbag.

dialogues.speaker: MOREHOUSE
dialogues.text: You're what I would call over qualified, Mr. Brown. What we want is a woman for three hours a night to clean around the window displays. You're a journalist.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: The Dixie Daily pocens t hire blacks. LF (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MOREHOUSE
dialogues.text: Is this a protest or something?

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: No, sir. I need the job. Morehouse shakes his head, begins to put the articles bac in the bag.

dialogues.speaker: MOREHOUSE
dialogues.text: I'm sorry.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: I can do anything a woman can do. Almost.

dialogues.speaker: MOREHOUSE
dialogues.text: No. The answer's no. No now, no tomorrow. No next week. No next year.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: What I like about this outfit is its open mindedness.

dialogues.speaker: MOREHOUSE
dialogues.text: I know what Mr. Bates wants. To be crude, Aunt Jemima. You look nothing like Aunt Jemima. You look like trouble. What Mr. Bates does not want is trouble. Clippings and awards back in the bookbag. Hands it back to Jack, smiles.

dialogues.speaker: MOREHOUSE
dialogues.text: -(continuing) Thank you for coming in. Miss Wellsley will give you a parking validation.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: My girl friend's trouble, Mr. Morehouse, not me.

dialogues.speaker: MOREHOUSE
dialogues.text: Your girl friend? What're you talking about?

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: She's the local legal staff +. the Southern Poverty Law enter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (CONT INUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 19 CONTINUED; Morehouse cupboard, Morehouse 11. (2)

dialogues.speaker: JACK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (smiles) She's very litigious. sinks perceptibly into his chair, opens a drinks an antacid.

dialogues.speaker: MOREHOUSE
dialogues.text: Is that meant to be amusing?

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: It's meant as a threat.

dialogues.speaker: MOREHOUSE
dialogues.text: On what grounds could she possibly sue? .

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: It's illegal to hire a woman if a more competent man is available for the job.

dialogues.speaker: MOREHOUSE
dialogues.text: More competent in whose opinion?

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: (yells) I'm not more competent than those deadbeat broads? Shall we have a carry a bucket of water up the escalator race? With all of them together? wipes his forehead with a large handkerchief.

dialogues.speaker: MOREHOUSE
dialogues.text: It's a terrible job, Mr. Brown, if truth be told, you wouldn't like it, you have to come in at noon on Tuesdays and Fridays to serve staff luncheons --

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: I worked my way through college waiting tables.

dialogues.speaker: MOREHOUSE
dialogues.text: As well as report at six p.m, every night of the week for three hours. The compensation is below --

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: I'll take it. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MOREHOUSE
dialogues.text: That bad out there?

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Worse. Morehouse plays his last card.

dialogues.speaker: MOREHOUSE
dialogues.text: How attached are you to that beard?

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Am I gonna vacuum with my beard? Come on, man, that shit went out with the sixties. Morehouse smiles, relieved, triumphant.

dialogues.speaker: MOREHOUSE
dialogues.text: We're all part of Mr. Bates' family here. In his family none of us wears. beards.

dialogues.speaker: ON JACK
dialogues.text: Reacting, digging in internally.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A clean-shaven Jack slides in the door. The kitchen is bustling with preparations for an elaborate luncheon for forty people. There are a dozen Aunt Jemima types in black uniforms, trimmed with white, the traditional white aprons and lace trimmed caps. RUBY DEE, an immense capabl black, turns with salad tongs and a scowl to Jack.

dialogues.speaker: RUBY DEE
dialogues.text: Whoever you want, she's busy. Come on back about three.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: I'm looking for Ruby Dee.

dialogues.speaker: RUBY DEE
dialogues.text: That's me. What about?

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: I'm the new cleaning lady. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: RUBY DEE
dialogues.text: Christ Almighty, Morehouse flipped his lid.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: He took pity on me, Mama, don't knock the dude.

dialogues.speaker: RUBY DEE
dialogues.text: (grins) Well, you sure gonna look weird in the uniform.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A long table set for a formal meal, complete with extra wine glasses, salad plates, butter plates, cold soup already at each of the forty places. There are forty executives, mostly men, in three piece Brooks Brothers suits and ties and conservative haircuts. The head accountant, Mr. Geffran, comes in from the hallw

dialogues.speaker: GEFFRAN
dialogues.text: (announcing) Mr. Bates is on his way. As a body, the executives move toward the table, talking in modulated, civilized tones. The waitresses come in, with serving dishes. Morehouse comes in.

dialogues.speaker: MOREHOUSE
dialogues.text: He's on the phone to London, five minutes. As a body they move away from the table. Ruby Dee comes in from.the kitchen.

dialogues.speaker: RUBY DEE
dialogues.text: He's off the phone. Sit, kids. Like a wave to the tables.

dialogues.speaker: TIGHT
dialogues.text: as Geffran and Morehouse sit together. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: GEFFRAN
dialogues.text: Anything interesting going on in personnel?

dialogues.speaker: MOREHOUSE
dialogues.text: Not really. In accounting?

dialogues.speaker: GEFFRAN
dialogues.text: Our move in Soybeans woke up the Justice Department. Cornering the market. (wipes his hands on his napkin) What's Bates supposed to do with his money? Whatever he buys he corners the market -- Spotting Jack, Morehouse chokes on his soup. Geffran slap him on the back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Midway in the line of waitresses carrying serving dishes, Jack," in the waitress uniform: the black dress, the whit apron, the trimmed cap. He is carrying a silver dish full of bread, wrapped in a linen napkin. A crystal bowl of butter balls on ice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the women circulate, serving butter, salad, pouring ic water, wine, etc., no one but Morehouse notices Jack. After all, he's black and wearing a uniform. Morehouse glances frantically around the table. Two as Jack leans over Morehouse's left shoulder, unwrapping the bread.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Bread, Mr. Morehouse?

dialogues.speaker: MOREHOUSE
dialogues.text: Get out of here, hurry, go, get some pants on, Mr. Brown, before Mr. Bates comes in. (CONT INUED)

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Butter? Morehouse loosens his tie, mops his forehead with his napkin. Jack grins, circles the head of the table, pulling the head chair back, cutting in between to pass the bread to the other side of the table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BATES comes in. Bates is Southern tradition, a good old boy with a wide stance, a ready smile and lethal eyes. He wears Brooks Brothers exclusively. Even his underwear is Brooks Brothers. Talk trails off. Everyone smiles toward the end of the table. The waitresses move toward his end, ready to serve him.

dialogues.speaker: BATES
dialogues.text: Good. Good. Time is money. Ruby Dee comes out of the kitchen before he gets to his chair.

dialogues.speaker: RUBY DEE
dialogues.text: Mr. Bates. Phone.

dialogues.speaker: BATES
dialogues.text: No calls.

dialogues.speaker: RUBY DEE
dialogues.text: It's your son.

dialogues.speaker: BATES
dialogues.text: (smiles, heads for kitchen) Oh. (to others) Excuse me.

dialogues.speaker: WITH BATES
dialogues.text: picks up the hall extension in the kitchen. BATES © Eric? How was the flight? I'm real glad you're here, son, we're going to have a real good week together. (smiles) Anything you want. Absolutely.  29 30 31 32 33 16.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bates strides over to the head chair, sits, pulls the table to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: as the table slides past them, maybe three feet. They look at it, then at each other, then at Bates, then try to sort it out without objecting.

dialogues.speaker: ON BATES
dialogues.text: Impervious to the chaos he's created, he begins to eat.

dialogues.speaker: ON WAITRESSES
dialogues.text: lined up behind him, serving him, one after another.

dialogues.speaker: ON JACK
dialogues.text: trying to sort out the plates. Passing them back and forth, collecting the ones on his arm that no one claims. And the glasses. And the forks. And the ashtrays.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Here. I think this one's yours. It isn't? Sir, did you have a blueberry muffin? Whose blueberry muffin is this? What kind of salad dressing did you have? Here. Isn't that yours? I think so. Well just take it, nobody's got any diseases. How about this one for you? Does this look like your fork? Working his way down the table, collecting more and more plates that people won't claim, can't find the correct person for, until O'BRIEN at the end, who is eating in his lap.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Like the soup?

dialogues.speaker: O'BRIEN
dialogues.text: Very much.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Want a card table? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: O'BRIEN
dialogues.text: If it wouldn't be too much trouble.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Not at all.

dialogues.speaker: O'BRIEN
dialogues.text: Thank you, Miss. Jack heads for the kitchen door. Bates points at him,

dialogues.speaker: BATES
dialogues.text: You. Jack looks behind himself, no one. Then approaches Bates.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Me?

dialogues.speaker: BATES
dialogues.text: Who are you?

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Your new cleaning woman, Mr. Bates. Bates nods.

dialogues.speaker: BATES
dialogues.text: Name?

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Brown. Jack Brown.

dialogues.speaker: BATES
dialogues.text: The women I employ, Mr. Brown, are required to wear hose or shave their legs. Do you have three dollars for a pair of hose?

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Not on me, but --

dialogues.speaker: BATES
dialogues.text: Then shave.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: My legs?

dialogues.speaker: BATES
dialogues.text: Yes. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Now?

dialogues.speaker: BATES
dialogues.text: (smiles) Right now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Still in his waitress uniform, one foot propped on the sink, Jack is trying to lather up the hair on his leg with the soap from the dispenser. Muttering. Then win- cing as he pulls the disposable razor through the mess. Other men using the facilities look at him strangely, then give him wide berth. Morehouse comes in.

dialogues.speaker: MOREHOUSE
dialogues.text: Brown? Good God. What're you doing?

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Shaving.

dialogues.speaker: MOREHOUSE
dialogues.text: Your beard, man, all I meant was your beard.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: (rinsing the razor) In the Bates family, we all shave our legs. Didn't you know? He told me himself. Smiles, exits. Morehouse looks after him a moment , Then picks up the razor, props his foot on the sink, slides up his pants. The door opens, Jack is there.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Schmuck! Vanishes, laughing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In one of the boarded up office buildings, a store front remains open. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: There are two black intellectuals, one man and one woman, each behind desks, on telephones. At the very back, Angela at her desk which is piled with papers, also on the phone. There are bookshelves full of lawbooks be- hind her. Around the walls posters celebrating the Klanwatch's activities. Jack is sitting in the chair across from Angela, his feet up on the desk, pissed.

dialogues.speaker: ANGELA
dialogues.text: (into phone, shrill) Seventy dollars? It's not possible! What're you lining them with, spun gold? (listens, gathers herself in hand) Of course do them, you goddam thief. I need brakes. And by five. (pleading) Five thirty. Yeah, okay. Hangs up, takes a breath to steady herself, grins at Jack

dialogues.speaker: ANGELA
dialogues.text: (continuing) I like your chin.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: (pulling up his | pant leg) Wait'll you see my calves. She comes around her desk, plops into his lap, laughing.

dialogues.speaker: ANGELA
dialogues.text: You got a job. That's what's important. That's what's terrific.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: It doesn't embarrass you to be living with a cleaning woman?

dialogues.speaker: ANGELA
dialogues.text: I think it's hysterical.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: I think I'm gonna quit. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: ANGELA
dialogues.text: We need money, Jack. I don't care if you pump gas or push a broom or teach school, but do something, something with a paycheck.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: I'm a journalist, goddammit, the only thing I'm comfortable doing is writing!

dialogues.speaker: ANGELA
dialogues.text: You don't wanna get married? He stares at her. Grins. They kiss.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Chrysler limousine arrives. A small boy emerges. Starts for the front door. Sees the crowd by the window, walks over. He is wearing a military school uniform. ERIC BATES, nine-years-old, thin, self-assured and arrogant.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack is running the vacuum cleaner around the lingerie exhibit, four mannequins in bras and teddies and bikinis in a bathroom set. By accident, he knocks against a mannequin with the vacuum cleaner hose. She topples over, crashing into the others, they fall like a house of cards, one smashing her hand on the vanity table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A fascinated crowd.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack has set two mannequins upright but in lifting #3 he knocks them over again. Looks, pained, at the mess around him, spots the broken hand. Picks it up. In doing so the vacuum cleaner cord becomes entangled, he ends on his ass.  40 ‘4L 42 43 44 45 46 21.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Some laugh. Some applaud. Some pull their children away. Barkely and Eric have gone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The chrome and glass displays of expensive things are cold and forbidding in the darkness of the cold store. Eric comes in, followed by a phalanx of blue-suited managers.

dialogues.speaker: GEFFRAN AND TOY MANAGER, (O'BRIEN)
dialogues.text: follow, muttering to each other.

dialogues.speaker: GEFFRAN
dialogues.text: Why do I have to stay for this? I'm accounting. Is he going to exceed his credit limit?

dialogues.speaker: O'BRIEN
dialogues.text: It's always the toy department. I wish he'd grow up. I wish he'd get interested in stereos.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eric stops. The men pile up behind him. The boy watches as Jack, unaware of his audience, tries to unscrew another mannequin's hand, with no success.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Give me a hand you tight-assed broad.

dialogues.speaker: ERIC
dialogues.text: smiles. The Managers are in a quandary as to what to do.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: gives up, picks up the broken hand, leaves her.

dialogues.speaker: ERIC
dialogues.text: suppresses a laugu, fossr:.  47 48 49 22.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: as Jack moves through the store encumbered with the broke hand trying to find a loose hand. The child and his re- tinue move along behind him, always out of sight, always watching.

dialogues.speaker: TOY DEPARTMENT
dialogues.text: Jack finds himself in the display of life-sized stuffed figures of superheros from the movies. He knocks Batman over by accident. Picks him up.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Sorry, Bat. Pats him on the shoulder. The Batman collapses again. Jack tucks the mannequins hand into his back pocket, sets up the Batman again.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: (continuing) On your feet, klutz. Bat collapses again. Jack lets out a sigh -- props him against Wonder Woman -- they nearly tip over -- he drags Superman into a sort of tri-pod arrangement.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: (continuing; to Wonder Woman) Live it up, darling.

dialogues.speaker: ERIC
dialogues.text: in the shadows turns to the blue-suited men behind him.

dialogues.speaker: ERIC
dialogues.text: That. The toy department manager comes forward, adjusting his tie, smiling.

dialogues.speaker: O'BRIEN
dialogues.text: The Batman?

dialogues.speaker: ERIC
dialogues.text: No. (points) Him. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: O'BRIEN
dialogues.text: Superman?

dialogues.speaker: ERIC
dialogues.text: The black man.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: whirls around in astonishment.

dialogues.speaker: MANAGERS
dialogues.text: Alarm and consternation.

dialogues.speaker: FEATURE ERIC
dialogues.text: O'Brien, the toy manager, is about to cry.

dialogues.speaker: O'BRIEN
dialogues.text: The black man.

dialogues.speaker: ERIC
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: O'BRIEN
dialogues.text: He's not a toy.

dialogues.speaker: ERIC
dialogues.text: I don't care.

dialogues.speaker: O'BRIEN
dialogues.text: He's one of our cleaning people, Eric.

dialogues.speaker: ERIC
dialogues.text: I want him.

dialogues.speaker: O'BRIEN
dialogues.text: He's not for sale.

dialogues.speaker: ERIC
dialogues.text: Why not?

dialogues.speaker: O'BRIEN
dialogues.text: Because he's... a person.

dialogues.speaker: ERIC
dialogues.text: Daddy said anything I wanted. Anything in the store. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: O'BRIEN
dialogues.text: You can't buy a human being, Eric.

dialogues.speaker: ERIC
dialogues.text: Why not?

dialogues.speaker: O'BRIEN
dialogues.text: Because you can't! The boy fixes him with a look. O'Brien finally crumbles.

dialogues.speaker: FEATURE JACK
dialogues.text: who watches as O'Brien adjusts his tie, hikes up his pant swallows and with tangible reluctance walks the distance to Jack, hand extended, jovial smile in place.

dialogues.speaker: O'BRIEN
dialogues.text: Tim O'Brien. Toys.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: (shakes the hand) Jack Brown. Windows.

dialogues.speaker: O'BRIEN
dialogues.text: The, uh, boy over there?

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Yes?

dialogues.speaker: O'BRIEN
dialogues.text: He's uh, the son of our, uh --

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Boss.

dialogues.speaker: O'BRIEN
dialogues.text: Right!

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: I can see a resemblance.

dialogues.speaker: O'BRIEN
dialogues.text: He, uh, would like to take you home with him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: O'BRIEN
dialogues.text: Just for a week. (CONTINUED)
Jack looks at him sideways, then at the boy, then at the manager.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Is he sick?

dialogues.speaker: O'BRIEN
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Nuts?

dialogues.speaker: O'BRIEN
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Then what are we talking about?

dialogues.speaker: O'BRIEN
dialogues.text: He's used to, uh, getting his own way.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Are you serious?

dialogues.speaker: O'BRIEN
dialogues.text: Very.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: You want me to go with him?

dialogues.speaker: O'BRIEN
dialogues.text: If you wouldn't mind.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Well, I would.

dialogues.speaker: O'BRIEN
dialogues.text: I don’t want him throwing a tantrum in my department, please, Mr. Brown.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: I don't give a damn where he throws his tantrum. The answer's no. O'Brien grabs him as he heads away, offers him a fifty dollar bill. Jack glares at him.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: (continuing) I'm not for sale, man. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: O'Brien palms him another fifty.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: (continuing) I mean it. We sorted that out in the Civil War. O'Brien thumbs out four more fifties, slowly, then tucks them into Jack's pocket.

dialogues.speaker: FEATURING ERIC
dialogues.text: as O'Brien propels Jack over to the child.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The gentleman will be delighted, Eric. His name is Jack Brown. Jack, this is Master Bates. Jack does a take, no one else seems to have heard. He extends his hand. Eric ignores it.

dialogues.speaker: ERIC
dialogues.text: I'll call him nigger.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: And I'll call you prick. Stunned silence. Then the child smiles.

dialogues.speaker: ERIC
dialogues.text: Wrap him up.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: What?! Eric's eyes flick dangerously toward the toy manager. He loosens his tie, sighs, takes Jack aside again. Two Jack is boiling. O'Brien soothing.

dialogues.speaker: O'BRIEN
dialogues.text: We'll make you very comfortable. Foam. A chair. A roomy box --

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Goddammit! (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: O'BRIEN
dialogues.text: (tucks another $50 into Jack's pocket) Mr. Brown, my house is mortgaged, twice, my wife's parents live with us. Her father is on dialysis, and even with Medicare, lemme tell you, it's a helluva struggle. One word from the boy and I'll lose my job. Jack glares at the child a moment.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: He needs a good whipping.

dialogues.speaker: O'BRIEN
dialogues.text: (another $50 into Jack's pocket) I really don't care what you do to him once you get there. Jack looks at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: as a large elegant Bates Department Store van sweeps unde the flowing cottonwoods along the drive up to the two- story house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The boy is sitting at the end of a long formal table, eating alone, except for a hatchet-faced MADEMOISELLE at his side, doing needlepoint. He's eating his peas one by one. He has not touched his liver. Or his sweet potatoes. He is leaning on his elbow, profoundly bored.

dialogues.speaker: MADEMOISELLE
dialogues.text: (in French) Elbows off the table. (nothing; in French) Sit up, Eric. (mothing; in French) Our stomachs will digest our food better if we eat some vegetable, some meat and some starch, in that order. Not all the vegetable at one time -- (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: ERIC
dialogues.text: I hate liver.

dialogues.speaker: MADEMOISELLE
dialogues.text: (in French) I understand nothing but French.

dialogues.speaker: ERIC
dialogues.text: I hate French. With a drink in his hand, Bates comes in as Mademoiselle is about to blow her stack. She settles quickly. Bates sits next to Eric, whiskey at hand. Eric plays with the peas on his plate.

dialogues.speaker: BATES
dialogues.text: So, how are you?

dialogues.speaker: ERIC
dialogues.text: Okay.

dialogues.speaker: BATES
dialogues.text: How's school?

dialogues.speaker: ERIC
dialogues.text: Okay.

dialogues.speaker: BATES
dialogues.text: Who are your friends?

dialogues.speaker: ERIC
dialogues.text: Dunno.

dialogues.speaker: BATES
dialogues.text: What classes do you enjoy?

dialogues.speaker: ERIC
dialogues.text: Dunno.

dialogues.speaker: . BATES
dialogues.text: How're your grades?

dialogues.speaker: ERIC
dialogues.text: Okay.

dialogues.speaker: BATES
dialogues.text: Don't they teach you to look a man in the eye when you talk to him?

dialogues.speaker: ERIC
dialogues.text: Yup.

dialogues.speaker: BATES
dialogues.text: Then why don't you? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: ERIC
dialogues.text: Because you're not my Commander in Chief. Barkley puts his head in the door.

dialogues.speaker: BARKLEY
dialogues.text: Excuse me. Eric, your present has arrived. Eric leaps to his feet, knocking over his chair, running toward the door. Mademoiselle springs to her feet, outraged.

dialogues.speaker: MADEMOISELLE
dialogues.text: (in French) Not until you eat your liver!

dialogues.speaker: BATES
dialogues.text: (overlapping) Eric! Eric ignores them both, flies out of the room. Bates sighs, downs his drink,

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The boy bursts in the door. It is a magnificent room, large and full of toys, a fort built of huge blocks of styrofoam, covered in bright-covered cloth and velcro, an electric train systems, a space shuttle device that hangs in the air, a Superman hang glider suspended from the ceiling, an air hockey game, slot machines, pinball machines, computers, typewriters. And in the middle of this, a wooden packing crate, dwarfed by the size and opulence of the room. Eric walks over to the box, touches it, a smile of triump on his face. Mademoiselle appears in the doorway.

dialogues.speaker: MADEMOISELLE
dialogues.text: (in French) Eric. Come and finish your dinner. Right now.

dialogues.speaker: ERIC
dialogues.text: Get me a hammer.

dialogues.speaker: MADEMOISELLE
dialogues.text: ¢in French) First you will finish -- (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: ERIC
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: MADEMOISELLE
dialogues.text: (in French) I'll tell your father.

dialogues.speaker: ERIC
dialogues.text: Get me a hammer!

dialogues.speaker: MADEMOISELLE
dialogues.text: (in French) If you don't come finish your dinner right now you won't open that till tomorrow.

dialogues.speaker: JACK'S VOICE
dialogues.text: Are you crazy! Mademoiselle jumps a foot. Bates appears in the doorway.

dialogues.speaker: BATES
dialogues.text: Eric --

dialogues.speaker: ERIC
dialogues.text: She won't help me open my present. She won't get me a hammer.

dialogues.speaker: MADEMOISELLE
dialogues.text: He hasn't touched his liver.

dialogues.speaker: JACK'S VOICE
dialogues.text: Help! Bates blinks, approaches.

dialogues.speaker: BATES
dialogues.text: What's this? Eric avoids his father's eyes.

dialogues.speaker: ERIC
dialogues.text: You said I could have anything in the store.

dialogues.speaker: JACK'S VOICE
dialogues.text: Would someone let me out of here! Eric finally meets his father's eyes. Silence.

dialogues.speaker: BATES
dialogues.text: “¢ (to Mademoiselle) 5 Get a hammer. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: She swallows her anger and rushes out. Bates touches the box.

dialogues.speaker: BATES
dialogues.text: (louder) Can you hear me in there?

dialogues.speaker: JACK'S VOICE
dialogues.text: Yes, sir.

dialogues.speaker: BATES
dialogues.text: Who are you?

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: The new part-time cleaning lady, sir. At the store. Jack Brown.

dialogues.speaker: BATES
dialogues.text: How did this happen?

dialogues.speaker: JACK'S VOICE
dialogues.text: I was doing my job, minding my business. Your son came along and asked them to wrap me up. Which they did. Bates paces, avoiding the boy's eyes, then whirls on him furious.

dialogues.speaker: BATES
dialogues.text: I hope you have an explanation of this.

dialogues.speaker: ERIC
dialogues.text: You said anything in the store. He was in the store.

dialogues.speaker: JACK'S VOICE
dialogues.text: Sir --

dialogues.speaker: BATES
dialogues.text: She's just coming with the hammer. Mademoiselle returns with the hammer, hands it to Bates.

dialogues.speaker: ERIC
dialogues.text: (taking the hammer) I get to open it. It's my present. He pries t!-2 néi?s’out, folds the top back with a SCREECHING OF NAILS. Jack stands stiffly, excelsior dripping from his hair, styrofoam clinging to his clothes (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: He impales the boy with a look, puts his hands on the edg of the box and jumps out, angry, with himself mostly.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: What the hell, for another couple of bucks I'd probably do it naked. Heads for door.

dialogues.speaker: BATES
dialogues.text: Sir --

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Naked, sir.

dialogues.speaker: BATES
dialogues.text: I mean come here a minute.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Forget it. Continues toward the door. Eric lobs a FIRECRACKER. It EXPLODES in front of Jack, who falls flat on his face. The boy, to his side, laughing. — ERIC We can have lots of fun, you and me.

dialogues.speaker: BATES
dialogues.text: I'll pay you on an hourly basis.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: I'd forgotten. The one thing I hate worse than white people is rich white people. Heads for the door again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: as Jack strides down the hall, Bates beside him.

dialogues.speaker: BATES
dialogues.text: What sort of full-time position would you be interested in, Mr. Brown?

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: "Slave' too cras7* —— (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: BATES
dialogues.text: I'm serious. Jack stops in the hall, faces the whale of a man.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: I am, too. I'm a newspaperman, Mr. Bates. I been without a job in this town for a year because you own the paper and you don't hire blacks. Unless they do windows. And wait tables. And kiss ass. (beat, grins) I just tried it. I don't like it. - Heads down the hall again. Bates beside him.

dialogues.speaker: BATES
dialogues.text: I only have him for a week, every year.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Get a better lawyer. You shouldn't have to have him that much.

dialogues.speaker: BATES
dialogues.text: I love him, Mr. Brown.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: I don't care!

dialogues.speaker: BATES
dialogues.text: He wants you to stay.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: He doesn't. He wants to see if you can make me stay. It's a power play. Manipulative little bastard.

dialogues.speaker: BATES
dialogues.text: If you were less hysterical, Mr. Brown, you might suggest that I pay you for the week, what I pay my reporters. A thousand dollars.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: (stunned) For babysitting? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Bates smiles, lethal. Jack looks down the hall at the kid, in exactly the same position as his father. Then bac at the man.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: (continuing; stunned) Is it inherited or contagious?

dialogues.speaker: BATES
dialogues.text: (smiles) Come down to my office.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Freestanding models of the Bates stores with a profit/los chart attached to each. Posters charting the demographics of the area: buying power per capita per county, driving habits, gas prices, advertising dollars, etc. On the wall facing Bates' desk, a blowup of the region with golden TV towers indicating each of his cable networks and golden threads connecting them to the central and tallest tower in Bates. On the wall behind the desk, life-sized portrai of Fancy as the Naked Raja, but with a string Bikini-bott in the shape of a heart over the critical area. Bates has his confederate flag standing discreetly in front of the boobs. Bates sinks into his leather chair, waves at Jack to take the chair across from him. One look at Fancy, peeking out from behind the flag, Jack averts his eyes and slides over to the chair, trying not to look at the painting, and at the same time, look at Bates. An impossibility. Bates watches him squirm a moment, then opens a box of cigars, passes them over.

dialogues.speaker: BATES
dialogues.text: I believe Eric sees more of me in this one week than he sees of his mother all year.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: This isn't by choice?

dialogues.speaker: BATES
dialogues.text: This is why I'm willing to pay you a thousand dollars to visit with us here. This is why I want him to have whatever he wants. This will all be his someday. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Jack clears his throat, takes a cigar, keeping his eyes on the floor.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Let's start at fifteen hundred, work up from there.

dialogues.speaker: BATES
dialogues.text: You're not a newspaper man, you're a crook.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: I'd take five hundred and a job on the paper.

dialogues.speaker: BATES
dialogues.text: There isn't a job on the paper.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Two thousand.

dialogues.speaker: BATES
dialogues.text: You're irritating me. Jack smiles, flicks the ash of his cigar in a Stuben hand

dialogues.speaker: BATES
dialogues.text: (continuing) That's not an ashtray.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: And what we're talking about's not a job. It's an insult. Bates dumps the ashes in the wastebasket, shoves over an ashtray.

dialogues.speaker: BATES
dialogues.text: Two thousand. For which you will wipe his ass if he wants you to. Jack smiles.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Three.

dialogues.speaker: BATES
dialogues.text: Two five.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Two seven. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: mo 36.

dialogues.speaker: BATES
dialogues.text: Two five's my top!

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Three.

dialogues.speaker: BATES
dialogues.text: You play poker?

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Only for money.

dialogues.speaker: BATES
dialogues.text: I wonder if Eric knows what a bastard he's getting. Jack looks him square in the eye.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: You only have him for a week. You spend three grand on a piece of jewelry for her -- (waves at the painting) -- and never think twice about it. But you won't spend it on your son? Nice guy. Bates is around the desk, Jack's shirt in his fist.

dialogues.speaker: BATES
dialogues.text: (through clenched teeth) Don't mess with me.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Two thousand five hundred'd be fine. Generous. Wonderful... Bates drops him, heads back to his desk. Jack adjusts his jacket, eases out the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Angela is sitting on the stoop with the rest of the block There's beer and ribs and laughter and music. It's not a party, it's just night. Angela has the phone pulled out onto the porch.

dialogues.speaker: ANGELA
dialogues.text: You at the store? (MORE) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: ANGELA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (beat) Hank Bates' house? The Hank Bates' house? (beat) Doing what? (beat) Jack, are you stoned, goddammit -- (silence) A toy? Hank Bates’ toy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack is in the phone booth which is a six-foot tall Micke Mouse. The person using the phone sits on Mickey's knees, talks into his ear.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: (into phone) Mr. Bates plays with his wife, I'm his son's toy. Eric emerges from the closet, pushing a Ferrari, carrying two helmets.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: (continuing; to Eric) How old are you?

dialogues.speaker: ERIC
dialogues.text: Nine.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: (into phone) He's nine. (sighs) Ange, Angela. Ask me how much I'm being paid. (beat) Of course I'm getting paid. You think I'd do this for fun? (beat) Two thousand five hundred. (beat) Of course, dollars. What'd you think, yen? (beat) Yeah. For one week.  63 64 38.

dialogues.speaker: TIGHT ON ANGELA
dialogues.text: She hangs up, stunned. Then leaps in the air, arms straight up as if it were a touchdown, yelling; with great love.

dialogues.speaker: ANGELA
dialogues.text: He did it! The crazy idiot did att

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fancy Bates, the blonde bombshell, is on a huge exercise machine which has the capacity to turn the body upside down, around, vibrate, massage, simultaneously. And is doing so. Bates comes in from the hall. Fancy is whirling and vibrating.

dialogues.speaker: BATES
dialogues.text: RAI ws -lheowe w= dni thes

dialogues.speaker: BATES
dialogues.text: I want to talk to you. Fancy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He watches a while, then turns off the machine. It slows. a ancy You get i TOO" machine, _then you won't let me use it. You're jealous of it. eae ee

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She slithers out of the machine, slips into the shower, flicks the skimpy leotard qver the door. tk emer (continuing _Is it about the party? Everything “s“arranged.— It’s going to be beautiful. : — Sethe

dialogues.speaker: BATES
dialogues.text: It's about Eric. Bates tries to peek over the top of the shower door, cannot quite, brings over a stool to stand on, it breaks under his weight, etc., during: (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: ‘AN

dialogues.speaker: BATES
dialogues.text: He bought a black man.

dialogues.speaker: BATES
dialogues.text: Bought a black man.

dialogues.speaker: FANCY
dialogues.text: I wasn't x EBD, sold then. qwesn es aware wher we sone

dialogues.speaker: BATES
dialogues.text: I didn't want you to be alarmed if you saw him around the house. He what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's a real live black man in

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: this house?

dialogues.speaker: BATES
dialogues.text: Just for a week. a Crancy But why?

dialogues.speaker: BATES
dialogues.text: To play with, he says. To irritate us, I think. Fance >

dialogues.speaker: BATES
dialogues.text: If we refuse to be irritated, take it calmly, it'll be less amusing to him. He'll be more likely to exchange it for Intellevision or something. Jesus. —_— Fancy emerges, wrapped in a towel, stares at him a moment in the wreckage of her dressing room.

dialogues.speaker: CY
dialogues.text: Heaven forbid you just told him no. a  65 '— 66 67 40.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The red, child-sized FERRARI SQUEALS out of the playroom, into the hall. Jack, knees to his chin, helmet perched on his head, hanging on for dear life, is in the passenger seat. Eric, goggles and helmet in place, is driving like a pro.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: I have a heart problem.

dialogues.speaker: ERIC
dialogues.text: We're not going very fast. It just seems like we are because we're close to the ground. SKIDS around a corner, hitting a potted palm broadside. It shatters as if hit by a bomb.

dialogues.speaker: ON JACK
dialogues.text: looking back, alarmed. His head whips forward.

dialogues.speaker: WITH CAR
dialogues.text: flying along the hall, SCREECHING to a halt from time to time.

dialogues.speaker: ERIC
dialogues.text: (pushes open door) My father's library. Driving, narrowly missing a statue, stopping.

dialogues.speaker: ERIC
dialogues.text: (continuing) Their bedroom. Driving, SCREECHING halt, door.

dialogues.speaker: ERIC
dialogues.text: (continuing) My playroom. Driving, SCREECHING to a halt, shoves open the door.

dialogues.speaker: ERIC
dialogues.text: (continuing) My room. Driving, stopping, kicking open the door. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: ERIC
dialogues.text: (continuing) Mademoiselle's. They knock over a statue, speeding around a corner on two wheels.

dialogues.speaker: FRONT STAIRS
dialogues.text: As the boy and the man in the car fly around the corner a the top of the carpeted stairs, cut too quickly, the car rolls down the carpeted stairs, Jack screaming, Eric laughing, colliding at the bottom with Barkley who is wheeling a table with a covered dinner for one on it, across the front hall. Food, silverware, glasses fly in every direction.

dialogues.speaker: ON BARKLEY
dialogues.text: stunned.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack eases himself out of the car, checking himself for damage. Eric is already on his feet, pulling the car over.

dialogues.speaker: ERIC
dialogues.text: I didn't figure your weight in the turn, that's all.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Jesus, Jesus, squeeze us with your hands of love. Eric hands him a cop's cap and a ticket pad.

dialogues.speaker: ERIC
dialogues.text: It wasn't my fault, Officer. He -- (pointing at Barkley) -- went through the yellow. Barkley, who is picking up food, glass, crockery and silverware, stands, waits.

dialogues.speaker: ERIC
dialogues.text: Give him a ticket.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Me? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: ERIC
dialogues.text: Write it up. Reluctantly, Jack puts the cap on, turns to brings out his wallet and papers.

dialogues.speaker: BARKLEY
dialogues.text: I'm sorry. Here's my license.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Hands over your head, up against the wall, spread 'em. Jack frisks him.

dialogues.speaker: BARKLEY
dialogues.text: That was your dinner.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Never mind.

dialogues.speaker: ERIC
dialogues.text: You're not allowed to talk to each other!

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: He's clean, sir, no blades, no rods, no knuckles, no dope, no bottles. (tears out ticket, hands it to Barkley) Best I can do is a warning. But, Pops, this is a serious warning. The streets of Bates are unsafe enough without boneheads like you running yellow lights with dinner tables and expired driver's licenses.

dialogues.speaker: BARKLEY
dialogues.text: Yes, sir, thank you, sir, I am sorry, sir.

dialogues.speaker: ERIC
dialogues.text: (laughs, applauds) Good! Come on. There's more to see. 42. Barkley, who Jack, puffed up like a cop, kicks the tires of the Ferrar and scowls at, the boy.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Just a minute... (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: ERIC
dialogues.text: What are you doing? We --

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Are you aware, sir, that your muffler is not modified correctly for street use, that your license plates are two years out of date, that your rear wheels are out of balance, that your car needs a wash, that to drive with an exposed rollbar is a misdemeanor, and that nobody with any class drives with brown goggles!

dialogues.speaker: ERIC
dialogues.text: (not amused) Get in.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Get out. A moment, then Eric decides to play. He gets out, pissed.

dialogues.speaker: ERIC
dialogues.text: I'll have them put you back on the beat. You don't mess with me, I'm Eric Bates.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: You're under arrest.

dialogues.speaker: ERIC
dialogues.text: I'm Eric Bates! My father'll --

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: I'm not arresting Megabucks, Shorty, I'm arresting you!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My father'll -- Jack collars him, looks at a closed door, then at arkley.

dialogues.speaker: BARKLEY
dialogues.text: The coat closet. Jack jerks it open, throws the kid in, amid sheepskin and mink and sede an4 camel's hair. Slams it shut and leans Dac sgainst it. SCREAMS. POUNDING. Barkley steps over the broken glass and broccoli, takes Jack's hand and shakes it.  71 72 44.

dialogues.speaker: STAIRS
dialogues.text: as Bates, wearing his dinner jacket, carrying a bottle of wine, comes up from the wine cellar.

dialogues.speaker: BATES
dialogues.text: What's going on here? . He pulls the closet door open. The boy stumbles out, red-faced and furious and breathing hard.

dialogues.speaker: ERIC
dialogues.text: He... ! He... Bates holds him by the shoulder, concerned.

dialogues.speaker: BATES
dialogues.text: Calm down. Get ahold of yourself. What happened?

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Sir, it was my fault, I --

dialogues.speaker: ERIC
dialogues.text: We were just playing, Daddy. In the silence, Eric smiles, takes Jack's hand, leads him toward the car again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eric is playing with the air hockey puck, the game turned off. Jack is at the window, watching the company arrive for a large party downstains.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Why did you cover for me?

dialogues.speaker: ERIC
dialogues.text: I want you to stay.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Why? Eric shrugs, studying the puck.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: It doesn't matter that I don't want to stay?

dialogues.speaker: ERIC
dialogues.text: Daddy's paying you (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: ‘That wasn't the question.

dialogues.speaker: ERIC
dialogues.text: If you're paid enough you'll stay.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: I have five friends, two turtles and an old lady.

dialogues.speaker: ERIC
dialogues.text: Your old lady won't mind.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: The turtles will.

dialogues.speaker: ERIC
dialogues.text: Play me a game.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: I'1l mind.

dialogues.speaker: ERIC
dialogues.text: If you win, you can go home. Jack looks over.

dialogues.speaker: ERIC
dialogues.text: (continuing) With pay.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: For the week?

dialogues.speaker: ERIC
dialogues.text: Sure.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Megabucks won't go for that.

dialogues.speaker: ERIC
dialogues.text: Sure he will.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: a thousand five hundred dollars or -- (watch) -- two hours?

dialogues.speaker: ERIC
dialogues.text: He won't mind.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: You don't know him very well, do you. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: ERIC
dialogues.text: (stamping his foot) I can deal with Daddy! Jack stares at him a long moment, then gets up, saunters over to the other end of the air hockey table.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: I used to be pretty good.

dialogues.speaker: ERIC
dialogues.text: I'm pretty good. Jack turns the game on. They WHANG it back and forth a minute.

dialogues.speaker: ERIC
dialogues.text: Every point I get you stay another year. Jack, reacting to that, misses a block. One point.

dialogues.speaker: ERIC
dialogues.text: (continuing) That's one year. Big smile. In the b.g. the staff is bringing in a daybed, a floor lamp, pillows, sheets, blankets. Pajamas, toilet supplies, anything for an excuse to come in and look at the man the boy bought. Mademoiselle comes over to them.

dialogues.speaker: MADEMOISELLE
dialogues.text: I've brought you pajamas, soap, a towel, a washcloth, slippers, a razor, shaving cream, toothbrush, toothpaste, if you'll leave your clothes in the hamper, we'll have them washed by morning. Jack whirls on the staff.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Is this the guided tour? How Many more are there?

dialogues.speaker: MADEMOISELLE
dialogues.text: Twenty, altogether.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Then you're coming in shifts?

dialogues.speaker: ERIC
dialogues.text: Your serve. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: (to staff) Get out! I'1l make the bed. Just leave the stuff and get out! They do so, in confusion. Jack, with anger in his _ eyes, brings his focus to the game.

dialogues.speaker: ON GAME
dialogues.text: The boy ZAPS another goal. Their eyes meet. Eric's laughing.

dialogues.speaker: ERIC
dialogues.text: Two years. Fast and furious play. Jack scores.

dialogues.speaker: ON COUNTER
dialogues.text: Jack slams over a bead.

dialogues.speaker: ON GAME
dialogues.text: The puck flies around, slams another point for Jack.

dialogues.speaker: ON ERIC
dialogues.text: who sets his mouth in a grim line.

dialogues.speaker: ERIC
dialogues.text: You are good.

dialogues.speaker: GAME
dialogues.text: faster, extended, the puck flashing and ricocheting. Finally careens into the boy's goal. Eric walks away, to the slot machine nearby.

dialogues.speaker: FULL
dialogues.text: Jack slams the counters over.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Get your butt back to the table, knucklehead. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: ERIC
dialogues.text: Nope.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: The game isn't over.

dialogues.speaker: ERIC
dialogues.text: I'm not playing.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: ‘Cause I'm about to whip you? ‘Cause you can't stand to lose?

dialogues.speaker: ERIC
dialogues.text: I just don't feel like playing anymore, that's all. Eric pushes a button, pulls a handle, gets a cup full of change. Plays on, seemingly indifferent. Jack walks over, leans on the machine.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: What if I told Megabucks?

dialogues.speaker: ERIC
dialogues.text: He doesn't care,

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: That you're a quitter? I don't believe it.

dialogues.speaker: ERIC
dialogues.text: He doesn't care what I am. As long as I stay out of his way. The pathos of that, true or not, reverberates in the Mademoiselle bustles in the door, full of self-importance.

dialogues.speaker: MADEMOISELLE
dialogues.text: Eric. It's bathtime.

dialogues.speaker: . ERIC
dialogues.text: I'm busy.

dialogues.speaker: MADEMOISEEL
dialogues.text: Come on now, the water's ready. Chop, chop.

dialogues.speaker: ERIC
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: MADEMOISELLE
dialogues.text: Eric. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: ERIC
dialogues.text: (playing) Not without my toy.

dialogues.speaker: MADEMOISELLE
dialogues.text: That's a good boy. With your boat? Or your rubber ducky?

dialogues.speaker: ERIC
dialogues.text: Jack. Silence.

dialogues.speaker: MADEMOISELLE
dialogues.text: Eric. I'm going to tell your father.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Does everybody say that?

dialogues.speaker: ERIC
dialogues.text: Yeah. Jack smiles, takes the boy's hand, heads for the door.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Bor-ing!

dialogues.speaker: ERIC
dialogues.text: (laughs) Yeah. They walk right by Mademoiselle, out of the playroom. She follows, at a loss.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A sunken tub full of bubbles. Jack comes in, Eric in tow, Mademoiselle behind them.

dialogues.speaker: MADEMOISELLE
dialogues.text: Not together! Not in the same water. Eric! You're too big to bathe with another person! Jack steps into the tub, shoes on, fully clothed. Eric laughs, then climbs to the other end.

dialogues.speaker: MADEMOISELLE
dialogues.text: : (continuing) Eric! I forbid you! (yelling) M. Bates! Vite! Vite! M. Bates!! (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: We all know he's downstairs with his guests. (unbuttoning his shirt, grins at Eric) Does she do backs? Mademoiselle vanishes, slamming the door.

dialogues.speaker: TIGHT TWO
dialogues.text: Eric smiles.

dialogues.speaker: ERIC
dialogues.text: I like you. Jack leans forward, pulls the boy's feet out from under him, dunking him. The boy comes up, spluttering and furious, slaps his hands flat on the surface, covering Jack in bubbles. Laughing, they fight, water and bubbles flying.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Soaking wet, carefully, Jack SQUISHES down the hall, trying not to get everything wet, regretting this day. Fancy, decked out for the party in something that holds up her breasts like they were religious offerings, comes out of her room, looks him up and down carefully.

dialogues.speaker: FANCY
dialogues.text: Don't tell me. Let me guess. You're the new second floor sprinkler system. I told them I wanted black pipes.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Jack Brown, Mrs. Bates. I'm sorry I'm getting the carpet wet. We ran out of dry towels. She looks him up and down, a little smile on her face.

dialogues.speaker: FANCY
dialogues.text: So. You're the toy. I wouldn't think this sort of thing would tickle a black man. Jack, lobdks her up and down, smiles. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Amazing, isn't it, what a person'1l do for money. She lets out an amazed whistle.

dialogues.speaker: FANCY
dialogues.text: God Almighty, I'd sure turn you in on Intellevision. She readjusts her left boob, lifting it a littler higher on it's platform in her dress, brushes by him as if he weren't here.

dialogues.speaker: ON JACK
dialogues.text: watching her go, his smile fading, the full extent of his humiliation clear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As he comes in, a pan of heavy cream, balanced on the door, tips over hin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Fancy comes down the stairs, the dinner guests are coming in. Black tie. Long dresses. The,men are_the local movers and shakers, not the blue bloods, they are by and large in their fifties, their wives, by and large are much younger and flashier. Fancy, seeing HONEY RUSSELL, bounces down the stairs and embraces her.

dialogues.speaker: FANCY
dialogues.text: Well you're looking better sugarpie, how're you feeling. The girls head for the living room, away from the crowd at the front door.

dialogues.speaker: TIGHT ON TWO
dialogues.text: HUGH RUSSELL, the local DA leans close to Bates.

dialogues.speaker: RUSSELL
dialogues.text: The word I get, Hank, is that they're going to indict you. (MORE) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: RUSSELL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (smiles, looks around) Where's the limey with the bourbon?

dialogues.speaker: TIGHT ON BATES
dialogues.text: reacts then smiles. Supercool.

dialogues.speaker: BATES
dialogues.text: (calls) Barkley!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack is lying on the daybed, scowling at the ceiling, dressed in bright red Spiderman pajamas. Scowling at one oversized toy after another, hanging from the ceiling, piled up against the wall, oppressive. The pinball machines, air hockey, trains, slot machines, phone booth, word processors. He gets to his feet, wanders among it all, hands behind his back, pacing.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: No, Mommy I do not want Intellevision, I want a nigger, Sally Ann Thompson has a nigger and she says hers plays basketball. I want one that says Ho Ho Ho, Fat Albert. Mommy, please? Everybody in my class has a nigger, please, Mommy, I want one too.

dialogues.speaker: INCLUDE ERIC
dialogues.text: who slips in from the closet, to hear better. Unnoticed.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: (as Hank Bates) It is a great idea, perhaps one of the great marketing ideas of our time, Morehouse, there is a raise in this for you without a doubt. We'll sell it like a Barbi doll. First the basic nigger. Then the outfits. Football outfits. Cotton-picking outfits. Rock star outfits. Shooting up outfits. (MORE) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: JACK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Then we'll sell ve-hicles. Pink Cadillacs. Cassettes. Books. Learn nigger in nine easy lessons. Maybe a Ku Klux Klan disposable nigger. Morehouse, I have not been this interested in life in many years. Trust me on this one. It'll be better for you, if I hold the patents in my name. Klanwatch might fry your ass, they won't mess with me. We'll saturate the South, can you imagine how this'll go in Jackson, Mississippi? Right after Thanksgiving. Then into the stores nationwide, a week before Christmas. That's how I sold the hula hoop. Eric knocks against a toy monkey that turns over, clapping. Jack looks over, startled.

dialogues.speaker: ERIC
dialogues.text: You're funny.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: You find that funny? Somehow I knew you would. And he walks out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The man and the boy in red pajamas walk down the hall, the boy mimicking the angry stride of the man. The man yanks open a door. It's the linen closet. SLAMS it shut, walks on, Eric yanks open the linen closet, SLAMS it shut, strides on.

dialogues.speaker: WITH JACK
dialogues.text: Pulls open the next door with considerably less authority.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mademoiselle is watching TV with her little poodle in her Jan. She looks over in irritation. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: I want my clothes back.

dialogues.speaker: MADEMOISELLE
dialogues.text: They're still wet.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: I want them now!

dialogues.speaker: MADEMOISELLE
dialogues.text: They're in the dryer.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: I want them back!

dialogues.speaker: MADEMOISELLLE
dialogues.text: Tante Pis. Eye to eye. Jack turns, abruptly, to Eric at his elbow.

dialogues.speaker: ERIC
dialogues.text: (translating) Tough Shit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the red Spiderman pajamas, Jack tiptoes down the stairs. The kid appears on the top of the stairs.

dialogues.speaker: ERIC
dialogues.text: Jack? Jack gives him the finger, continuing down the stairs.

dialogues.speaker: ERIC
dialogues.text: (continuing) Where you going?

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Home.

dialogues.speaker: ERIC
dialogues.text: Why? Jack stops, looks back at the boy.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Are you that dumb? “~~ ( Heads .u. the da.  93 co 94 o5 55.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fancy comes out of the dining room, heads across the front hall. Stops and smiles at Jack.

dialogues.speaker: FANCY
dialogues.text: Well, aren't we full of surprises.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: I was looking for the laundry room, Mrs. Bates.

dialogues.speaker: FANCY
dialogues.text: (smiles, then) Right this way, Mr. Brown.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The dining room is full of elegant people in black tie and long dresses. Fancy pushes Jack into the room. Stunned silence. Bates to his feet, furious, strides to them, during:

dialogues.speaker: FANCY
dialogues.text: I just wanted y'all to see what Hank bought his boy today. It doesn't even need batteries. Isn't that sweet? I'm hoping it'll start a trend. Do something about the awful unemployment situation. Now would any of y'all like one of ‘em for your children? I believe we take orders -- Bates takes Fancy by one arm, Jack by the other, the astonished talk rising behind them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The three emerge from the dining room.

dialogues.speaker: FANCY
dialogues.text: Christ Almighty, Hank, you're such a pompous ass. Can't you take a joke?

dialogues.speaker: BATES
dialogues.text: I didn't find it remotely amusing. (to Jack) Did you? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Maybe remotely. If you weren't you or me.

dialogues.speaker: FANCY
dialogues.text: You're marking my arm, sugar. ‘He lets go, his anger as undiminished as his smile.

dialogues.speaker: BATES
dialogues.text: I thought three times a week with the pink shrink in New Orleans was enough.

dialogues.speaker: FANCY
dialogues.text: Tt tis. tom sorry. © was, just bragging on you. You used to like for me to brag on you. How'm I supposed to know when you're having your period? He grabs her arm again, in a rage.

dialogues.speaker: BATES
dialogues.text: I think you need some quiet time in the hospital.

dialogues.speaker: FANCY
dialogues.text: Let loose of me.

dialogues.speaker: ERIC
dialogues.text: Let loose of my nigger. Bates looks up, takes a deep breath, smiles.

dialogues.speaker: BATES
dialogues.text: We don't use that word in this house, Eric. Black or colored person. Not nigger.

dialogues.speaker: ERIC
dialogues.text: Let loose of my colored person. Moment, then Bates takes Fancy by the arm and propels her into the dining room, slamming the door behind them. Jack looks at the little boy at the top of the stairs, arms around his legs, waiting.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: So long, white person. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: ERIC
dialogues.text: Come back upstairs, Jack.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: No way.

dialogues.speaker: ERIC
dialogues.text: You can't leave.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: I can. I walk out that door. Simple

dialogues.speaker: ERIC
dialogues.text: In your pajamas?

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: The frog's got my clothes.

dialogues.speaker: ERIC
dialogues.text: You won't get paid.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: You think the only thing that Matters is the money?

dialogues.speaker: ERIC
dialogues.text: You said it was, a while back.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: I was wrong. Heads for door.

dialogues.speaker: ERIC
dialogues.text: Was I bad. Jack looks back up him. Almost feels sorry for him, smiles.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Bad? What you are gives new meaning to the word. Winks, steps onto a foyer chair, holds a match under the sprinkler head.

dialogues.speaker: ON ERIC
dialogues.text: starts to giggle.  97 98 99 100 58.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The sprinkler system goes off. Over everyone. SCREAMING. Chaos.

dialogues.speaker: ON BATES
dialogues.text: Continues to eat, furious, controlled.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: as Jack comes in, wincing with every step, straight to the sink, runs some water, sits on the drainboard, eases both feet in, trying not to scream with the pain. Angela, working at her desk, watches this, rubs her eyes, shakes her head, puts on her glasses, peers at him again.

dialogues.speaker: ANGELA
dialogues.text: What are you wearing?

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: My feet are bloody stumps. Angela crosses to him, laughing.

dialogues.speaker: ANGELA
dialogues.text: And for all these years I thought Spiderman swung through the air on ropes of spit. (arms around him) My God, they are bloody stumps.

dialogues.speaker: JACKS
dialogues.text: My wallet's in my pants pocket which is in the dryer in Mr. Bates' house which is halfway to Alaska. My bike's at the store. I tried hitchhiking. But there was some reluctance to pick me up. She pours a bottle of antiseptic into the water. He screams. They wrap their arms around each other, tight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The boy is playing the Space Invaders machine. It makes alot of noise and takes alot of concentration. Bates, in his soaking wet dinner clothes, opens the door. The boy continues playing the game. Bates takes a deep breath, willing himself patient, suvcx: 3sing*:_ the irritation, pasting on the smile. He shoves his hands in his pockets, walks to the game machine as if he had all the time in the world. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: ERIC
dialogues.text: I want to go back to school.

dialogues.speaker: BATES
dialogues.text: Before the end of spring vacation?

dialogues.speaker: ERIC
dialogues.text: Tonight.

dialogues.speaker: BATES
dialogues.text: But this is my week.

dialogues.speaker: ERIC
dialogues.text: I knew you wouldn't let me. Vaves of anger within Bates, finally, icy:

dialogues.speaker: BATES
dialogues.text: Why? What's happened? Did you want to come down and see what a mess you made?

dialogues.speaker: ERIC
dialogues.text: I didn't do it.

dialogues.speaker: BATES
dialogues.text: Then Jack Brown did. For you. Eric whirls on him, red faced with anger.

dialogues.speaker: ERIC
dialogues.text: It's always my fault! Well it wasn't my fault. It was Fancy's! She didn't have to take him into the dining room and make everybody laugh at him! Now he's gone and he won't come back no matter how much you pay him and I don't want to stay here if he's not here ‘cause I don't have anyone to play with. To a point of hysteria. Bates grabs him and holds him half to restrain him half to comfort him. Eric fights like the very devil, kicking and punching and finally wrenching free. He stands panting, backing away from his father. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: BATES
dialogues.text: I don't like to see these tantrums, Eric. Eric stomps his feet and shrieks.

dialogues.speaker: ERIC
dialogues.text: I want him back! Bates blows out a breath of exasperation, crosses to the Mickey Mouse telephone. Eric turns it off like he turned it on.

dialogues.speaker: ERIC
dialogues.text: (continuing) Two to one you can't. Bates smiles.

dialogues.speaker: BATES
dialogues.text: Ten to one I can. The boy smiles. Bates dials Mickey's ear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They are in each other's arms, quiet.

dialogues.speaker: ANGELA
dialogues.text: I think you did the right thing.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: I shaved off my beard for nothing.

dialogues.speaker: ANGELA
dialogues.text: It'll grow back. He leans over her, covers her mouth with his. Long kiss.

dialogues.speaker: ANGELA
dialogues.text: (continuing) We can move.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: You love your job.

dialogues.speaker: ANGELA
dialogues.text: I love you more. Deep kiss. DOORBELL, Their eyes open.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: They've come for the pajamas. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: ANGELA
dialogues.text: (yells) We'll send them in the morning! , DOORBELL. Jack gets up with great reluctance. on a pair of jeans.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Maybe they're bringing back my clothes. I kind of like that jacket. Only thing I owned came from the Bates Department Store.

dialogues.speaker: INT/EXT FRONT DOOR
dialogues.text: 6l. Pulls Jack opens the door. Morehouse is there, looking much the worse for the wear. The limo is parked at the curb. Barkley is leaning on a fender, lighting his pipe. Jack looks at Morehouse, then starts to close the door. Morehouse puts a hand on it, bracing it open.

dialogues.speaker: MOREHOUSE
dialogues.text: Please --

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: The boy needs a shrink, Mr. Morehouse, not me.

dialogues.speaker: MOREHOUSE
dialogues.text: I agree with you. Nonetheless --

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Mr. Morehouse, go home, the answer's no. No, now. No. tomorrow. No, regardless of the compensation. With shaking hands Morehouse draws an envelope out of his pocket, hands it to Jack.

dialogues.speaker: MOREHOUSE
dialogues.text: I take sleeping pills, Mr. Brown, I had just dropped off. I feel like bloody hell. He said if I wasn't willing to do what he wanted when he wanted, I could look for another job. So, once again, I am doing what he wants, when he wants, regretting it. (MORE) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MOREHOUSE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (beat) The bright side of the coin is I believe I have a terminal ulcer. (smiles) I admire your moral fiber, Mr. Brown. He heads for the street. Jack looks at the check in the envelope.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Jesus. This is for the week? Or for the rest of my life?

dialogues.speaker: MOREHOUSE
