dialogues.text: He said you let that black man serve. I said Mr. Bates, Mr. Morehouse hired him, I didn't hire him, my job is to use the people he hires, not to question his choices. And he said you're fired. I been Head of Food Service for the Bates Department Store for nineteen years. Two more months my pension woulda taken care of the kids.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: And you didn't say anything?

dialogues.speaker: RUBY DEE
dialogues.text: Like what?

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Like wait a second, what are you doing to my life! Ruby Dee laughs, rich and resonant.

dialogues.speaker: ERIC
dialogues.text: Can I take your picture?

dialogues.speaker: RUBY DEE
dialogues.text: (grins, touches her hair) Well sure, precious.

dialogues.speaker: PHOTO
dialogues.text: Ruby Dee, surrounded by her flock of children, grinning, pleased.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The bike is leaning on the Chrysler. The recorder on the roof. Barkley is polishing the chrome, avoiding everybody eyes. Eric is snapping pictures.

dialogues.speaker: BARKLEY
dialogues.text: You're sure this is all right with Mr. Bates?

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Whatever the kid wants is all right with Bates. You know that. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Polishing. Polishing.

dialogues.speaker: ERIC
dialogues.text: It's all right.

dialogues.speaker: BARKLEY
dialogues.text: Well. I was in the employ of Lord Cavendish, a man as enamored o billiards as Mr. Bates. (beat) They met in a queue outside the Old Vic. (beat) My Lord won a herd of cattle in ‘78 from Mr. Bates. One hundred registered Herefords. Mr. Bates sent them over on a 747. (sighs) In '79, Mr. Bates won me.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: You? Cavendish bet you?

dialogues.speaker: BARKLEY
dialogues.text: Mr. Bates insisted. My Lord wanted to bet the castle. Mr. Bates said he didn't want a eight-hunner-year old pile of rocks, is the way I believe he put it. What he wanted was a butler.

dialogues.speaker: ERIC
dialogues.text: Maybe Cavendish'1l get better at pool.

dialogues.speaker: BARKLEY
dialogues.text: (smiles) Please God. They are walking side by side, eating Eskimo pies.

dialogues.speaker: ERIC
dialogues.text: If my father's rotten does it mean I'm gonna be rotten too?

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Probably. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: ERIC
dialogues.text: What if I don't wanna be? Jack bumps against him. Eric's ice cream slides off his stick, down his sleeve, down his shirt, down his pants, o his shoe. They watch it happen, then look at each other. Jack laughs. Laughing, Beat.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: You're hopeless. Adjust yourself to that.

dialogues.speaker: ERIC
dialogues.text: (laughing) I don't mind. You're hopeless too. Jack takes his hand.

dialogues.speaker: ERIC
dialogues.text: (continuing) What's Angela like? JACK” Angela? Is this part of the same conversation? Were we talking about your father?

dialogues.speaker: ERIC
dialogues.text: (laughing) Tell me, Jack.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: She's like the Statue of Liberty. Give me your tired, your poor, your huddled masses. Loves causes. Loves to boil with righteous : indignation. She's what your father would call a pinko.

dialogues.speaker: ERIC
dialogues.text: Do you mate a lot?

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: 'Mate?' Animals 'mate,' Eric.

dialogues.speaker: ERIC
dialogues.text: Well, screw.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: None of your goddamn business. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: ERIC
dialogues.text: What's it like?

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Jesus, doesn't anyone talk to you? Ask your dad.

dialogues.speaker: ERIC
dialogues.text: What do you do with your thing?

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Screwing's like dying. When the time comes, you'll know what to do. During which, Jack hoists him onto his shoulders, hands him up his ice cream, walks on, an elbow cocked over the sticky sneaker. Eric lets the ice cream slide off the cone, into Jack's hair. Nearly falls off his shoulders, laughing. INT. PLAYROOM - DAY . Jack is leaning over the boy's shoulder at the desk, Eric is arranging the photos and the "articles" of newsprint. Jack is rearranging them. 0

dialogues.speaker: ERIC
dialogues.text: What'1l we call it?

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Truth, Justice and the American Way.

dialogues.speaker: ERIC
dialogues.text: And get sued by Superman.

dialogues.speaker: JACK

dialogues.speaker: ERIC

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Advertising by Fredericks of Hollywood? Eric takes a photo Jack moves, moves it back to where he had it. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: ERIC
dialogues.text: Stop moving that. It belongs here. It balances this and this, dumbo.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: You're right.

dialogues.text: At The Dixie Daily.

dialogues.text: Yeah? So what?

dialogues.text: You are dense. .

dialogues.speaker: JACK

dialogues.text: We need a press, don't we? It's the only press in town, isn't it? Jack looks at the boy slowly.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: We're going to run this off on the press at The Dixie Daily? Eric rolls his eyes heavenward.

dialogues.speaker: ERIC

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.text: We could call it Half-Assed.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: You don't think it'll irk your father? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: ERIC
dialogues.text: It's going to irk my father anyway.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: (shaking his head) Negative. Zip. Terrible terrible idea.

dialogues.speaker: ERIC
dialogues.text: We could call it Chickenshit. Beat. Jack looks at his watch.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Cover your tracks with the frog. Tell her we're camping out on the river or something. He begins putting the layout in a portfolio. Eric races out of the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Edging alongthe shadows, Jack and Eric (who is carrying the big portfolio) creep around the corner, to a side door.

dialogues.text: as Jack, with an elaborate jimmying tool, begins to work gingerly on the lock. Eric watches him a moment.

dialogues.speaker: ERIC
dialogues.text: Were you ever a thief?

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: (jumps a foot) Shhhh.

dialogues.speaker: ERIC
dialogues.text: Were you?

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Of course. It's part of the black cultural imperative. Don't you know anything? Laughing, Eric hands him the portfolio. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: ERIC
dialogues.text: Hold this. Then Eric pulls out a key, unlocks the upper lock, then the lower one.

dialogues.speaker: ERIC
dialogues.text: (continuing) If you open the lower one first eight million alarms go off. All Diebolt locks are like that. They go in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: as they walk softly down the silent dark halls, Jack carrying the portfolio, following the kid.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: It is uncool to be smarter than the people who are trying to teach you something, Junior. They resent it. They turn on you when you least expect it --

dialogues.text: Where are the lights?

dialogues.text: The alarms go off if you turn them on after hours.

dialogues.speaker: JACK

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: (continuing) Were you evor a thief? eye “  142 143 144 145 90.

dialogues.speaker: AT PRESS
dialogues.text: Jack is setting the type, putting in the photos, setting the headlines. Eric redoes it all, changing it all, learning.

dialogues.speaker: ERIC
dialogues.text: We really could put out a paper Scoop. Jack smiles and pushes the button for one copy.

dialogues.speaker: ERIC
dialogues.text: (continuing) I mean it.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: We really are putting out a paper Scoop.

dialogues.speaker: ERIC
dialogues.text: I mean every week. You and me. Not just about Daddy. About everything else that's wrong with this city. We could charge a dime. People'd buy it because it was cheap. And we could change them. And I wouldn't have to go back to school. As the first copy, the test copy, comes out of the press, Jack takes it.. CAMERA COMES AROUND TO SEE, for the first time, the second page. Photos of Geffran, Ruby Dee, Barkley, articles under each. Turns it over. A banner photo of Fancy as The Naked Raja. And the headline: "The Toy."

dialogues.text: pushes in 1000, starts the presses, turns to Jack.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: grins. Holds his hands out. They slap each other's hands. Bump hips, elbows, shoulders, laughing.

dialogues.text: One black and white is parked by the building. Another pulls up behind it. The ramrod-straight, dark-haired, mustached COP, older than the sthers, is lighting a cig- avette as the othe= “©. + cume ver... t (CONTINUED)

dialogues.text: CoP We have ascertained that people are within said structure. How many and how heavily armed is as yet undetermined --

dialogues.text: as the cops emerge from every direction. Guns drawn.

dialogues.text: Don't move or we shoot! Eric turns, irritated mostly, heads for the Cop. ERIC © Don't you know who I am -- Jack grabs him, claps a hand over his mouth, holds him still. Holds his other hand in the air in surrender.

dialogues.text: Jack is sitting in the booking chair. The activity of the office is normal for 10 PM. Drunks and hookers and vagrants. The cops are mostly white, the apprehended mostly black. Eric is on Jack's knee. Ignored. They are muttering to each other.

dialogues.text: If we call your father, he'll ask them where they picked us up, clown.

dialogues.text: What about Barkley?

dialogues.speaker: JACK

dialogues.text: He hates Dad.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Hate doesn't counc. ‘Paychec*s ‘count. daven't you learned anything? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.text: Then Angela?

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: It'll take her a couple of days. Plus she'd want some explanation.

dialogues.speaker: ERIC
dialogues.text: I could throw a tantrum.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: This is a grown-up problem, Eric. We have to deal with it ina grown-up way.

dialogues.text: The presses are silent. The folded papers spilled onto the floor.

dialogues.text: Pandemonium. Eric is throwing a tantrum, yelling bloody murder, pretending it's a war, leaping desk to desk shooting everyone with a fire extinguisher. Jack is pulling file cabinets over, blocking aisles and passages.

dialogues.text: lobs a string of firecrackers.

dialogues.speaker: FULL
dialogues.text: The firecrackers go off in the midst of the cops. The cops, thinking it's gun fire, dive for the protection of overturned desks and chairs, return the fire. Between the battle lines, on the floor, Jack and Eric scuttle out, like Marines in the trenches.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eric and Jack are giving out papers at the ewp’:ye2s' entrance, (CONTINUED)

dialogues.text: Eric yawns broadly, then catches himself, glances worried at Jack who hasn't seen him, hands a paper to an employee

dialogues.speaker: ERIC
dialogues.text: It's free, take it.

dialogues.speaker: ON JACK
dialogues.text: as he hands it to the toy manager, who looks at the boy, Jack, then opens the paper. Closes it quickly, turning pale, slips a ten into Jack's hand, quickly, nervously.

dialogues.speaker: O'BRIEN
dialogues.text: Forget I know you. Returns the paper. Vanishes into the building.

dialogues.text: Eric and Jack are distributing the paper to people going

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everybody's reading the paper, leaning on desks, in huddl getting no work done, astonished.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Morehouse, sweating, easing his tie, wiping his hands on his handkerchief, is pacing up and down outside of the executive elevator. The light indicates that it is coming up from the parking lot. Morehouse nearly expires. The doors open. Bates lumbers out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Morehouse strides along about half a step behind Bates.

dialogues.speaker: MOREHOUSE
dialogues.text: "Morning, Mr. Bates. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: BATES
dialogues.text: ‘Morning.

dialogues.speaker: MOREHOUSE
dialogues.text: Sir, this morning -- Bates rounds the corner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bates stops, blinks. Chaos as people try to hide the papers, get to their desk, appear to be working.

dialogues.speaker: BATES
dialogues.text: (to Morehouse) Take their names. He strides through to his office, leaving havoc behind hi

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Bates moves to his chair. Morehouse uncurls the paper from under his arm.

dialogues.speaker: MOREHOUSE
dialogues.text: This was distributed at the employee entrance by your son and Mr. Brown. You better take a look at it. Bates glances at it. Stops. Looks through it, scowling. Photos, stories, lots of exclamation marks. Bates grows harder and meaner and madder by the moment.

dialogues.speaker: BATES
dialogues.text: Eric is responsible for this?

dialogues.speaker: MOREHOUSE
dialogues.text: And Jack Brown.

dialogues.speaker: BATES
dialogues.text: I want them in my office as soon as possible. Morehouse hurries out of there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack and Eric are each in a bumper boat, each full] throttle, heading straight for each other.  163 164 165 166 167 168 169 95.

dialogues.speaker: ERIC
dialogues.text: The boy is bent over his steering wheel, elbows cocked, a look of maniacal glee on his face.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: at the last minute, shuts his eyes, covers his head with his arms and screams.

dialogues.speaker: COLLISION
dialogues.text: Water, boats and flying bodies fill the screen.

dialogues.speaker: FULL
dialogues.text: Eric's boat, miraculously, is still upright, though half full of water. He pulls Jack out of the lake, laughing.

dialogues.speaker: ERIC
dialogues.text: Come to Houston with me, Jack. We'd have such: fun.

dialogues.speaker: ON JACK
dialogues.text: as he collapses into the boat, spluttering, his eyes on something over the boy's shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Over the crest of the hill behind the house, the Chrysler doing ninety.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Eric. The shit has hit the fan.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bates is reading the paper. KNOCK. He raises his eyes to the door. Morehouse opens the door. Jack and Eric come in.

dialogues.speaker: MOREHOUSE
dialogues.text: Would you have me stay or go, sir?

dialogues.speaker: BATES
dialogues.text: How many of these did you pass out? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: ERIC
dialogues.text: A thousand.

dialogues.speaker: BATES
dialogues.text: (to Morehouse) I want every one accounted for. And shredded. Send Carter. I want you back here.

dialogues.speaker: MOREHOUSE
dialogues.text: Yes, sir. He hurries toward the door. Morehouse

dialogues.speaker: ERIC
dialogues.text: We're going to make twice as many tomorrow and sell them and pay you back and --

dialogues.speaker: BATES
dialogues.text: You are not.

dialogues.speaker: ERIC
dialogues.text: We are.

dialogues.speaker: BATES
dialogues.text: Mr. Brown, I assume you know the penalties for libel?

dialogues.speaker: ERIC
dialogues.text: There's nothing in there everybody doesn't know.

dialogues.speaker: BATES
dialogues.text: If I say it's a lie, it's a lie. comes in, panting.

dialogues.speaker: ERIC
dialogues.text: But it's the truth.

dialogues.speaker: BATES
dialogues.text: (angry) Truth has nothing to do with reality, Eric. What you have to deal with is reality. In reality every one of these people, with a little persuasion will say whatever I tell them to say. (smiles, icy) I'm reality. (beat) Morehouse, take off your pants. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MOREHOUSE
dialogues.text: Sir?

dialogues.speaker: BATES
dialogues.text: Take off your pants. Right now. Right this minute.

dialogues.speaker: MOREHOUSE
dialogues.text: Right here?

dialogues.speaker: BATES
dialogues.text: If you value your job. This is hard for Morehouse. He squirms. He reviews his options. He starts to object. And, eventually, he drops his pants, stands uncomfortable and humiliated. Bates let him stand there a long time.

dialogues.speaker: BATES
dialogues.text: (continuing; to Eric) That's reality. (to Morehouse, disgusted) Get dressed. Morehouse pulls on his pants.

dialogues.speaker: MOREHOUSE
dialogues.text: You asked me, sir.

dialogues.speaker: BATES
dialogues.text: (to Eric) People will do anything for me. When you grow up, they'll do anything for you. He looks a long moment at the front of the paper then directly to Brown.

dialogues.speaker: BATES
dialogues.text: (cont inuing) If you worked for my paper you couldn't write this. You'd have to see things my way. You'd have to take off your pants when I told you to. Silence.

dialogues.speaker: BATES
dialogues.text: (continuing) You want to do that? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Silence. Silence. 98. (3)

dialogues.speaker: BATES
dialogues.text: (continuing) You want to kiss ass?

dialogues.speaker: BATES
dialogues.text: (continuing; to Eric) I want you to want to stop this. I want you to see the value in stopping this. (smiles) I'll give your black friend a real job on a real paper, writing news, on The Dixie Daily. Eric looks at Jack who meets his eyes. Long moment.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: No. I don't like kissing ass. No, thank you.

dialogues.speaker: ERIC
dialogues.text: Wait. It's what you wanted. It's what you're good at.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Kissing ass?

dialogues.speaker: ERIC
dialogues.text: Writing for a paper. (to Bates) We'll stop, Daddy. Jack looks at the boy astonished.

dialogues.speaker: BATES
dialogues.text: Now you're learning something. (stand, shakes Jack's hand) Welcome again to the Bates family, You want to start tomorrow?

dialogues.speaker: ERIC
dialogues.text: He's mine till tomorrow.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: I think this means I'm fired as your toy. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.text: You're having a party tomorrow. There won't be anybody to play with. He can start at the paper Monday. Bates smiles at Jack.

dialogues.speaker: BATES
dialogues.text: The power behind the throne.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack and Eric turn out of the front doors. Eric is walking with his hands in his pockets, like Jack usually does. Jack leaps high into the air with a yell, then apologizes to the startled passersby, and walks on with the boy.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: It's called snatching triumph from the jaws of disaster. Eric walks on. Jack bouncing alongside like a rubber ball.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: (continuing) You did a really good thing in there, you know? Eric walks on, hands shoved in his pockets. Jack leaps into the air again, slamming his fist against a bus standard, like a basketball player.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: (continuing) You know what it feels like to have a job? A real job? It feels grrrrreat! Eric unlocks the bike, swings his leg over, pedalling slowly, along the sidewalk, Jack on foot alongside.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: (continuing) Angela's gonna shit watermelons.

dialogues.speaker: ERIC
dialogues.text: Gross. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Unheard. 100.

dialogues.text: No, thanks.

dialogues.text: Not funny.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Eric?

dialogues.speaker: ERIC
dialogues.text: What're we celebrating?

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Hey --

dialogues.speaker: ERIC
dialogues.text: Monday morning my father's gonna tell you to take off your pants in front of the world and you're gonna do it. (beat) He treats people like turds, Jack, didn't you read our paper, didn't you hear what those people said, didn't you want to kick Mr. Morehouse in the nuts? (anger in his voice, liquid eyes) Headline... Jack Brown sold out today to Hank Bates. As expected.

dialogues.text: You're the one who said we'd stop! I said no!

dialogues.speaker: ERIC
dialogues.text: You didn't mean it. You can't wait to start work Monday. Jack grabs him. Nearly an accident. They are on a street corner. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.text: You want me to starve? Can I pay for groceries with high-handed principles? It's fine for you, growing up, to believe in truth and justice and the American way, but once you're grown up you play grown-up games.

dialogues.text: You could've come to Houston with me.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: (angry) As your shoeshine boy?

dialogues.speaker: ERIC
dialogues.text: As my friend! The old VW bus with the Klanwatch logo on the side lurche around the corner to park in the red. Angela leaps out.

dialogues.text: Jack! Embrace.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Angel. Meet Eric Bates. My friend Eric Bates. Angela grabs Eric by the arm, shakes him.

dialogues.text: You're the one? What gives you the idea that you can buy people! You spoiled little -- Jack pulls her off.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Cool it, he --

dialogues.speaker: ANGELA
dialogues.text: Someone needs to give him a paddling, people have rights and dignity and if you --

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Ease off. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.text: She looks at him, finally hearing, dumbfounded.

dialogues.speaker: ANGELA
dialogues.text: Ease off?!

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: It's okay.

dialogues.speaker: ANGELA
dialogues.text: It's okay what he's done to you?

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: He got me a job, Ange, writing news for the Dixie Daily. Starting Monday, Angela looks from one to the other.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: (continuing) Nobody's happy. Except me.

dialogues.text: We're picketing his house tomorrow.

dialogues.text: You're what?

dialogues.text: (to Jack) His Daddy's having a fundraiser for the Klan's Youth Camps. ‘Silence.

dialogues.text: as Jack, with the kid on the bar, pedals through downtown Bates. Eric steers, Jack pedals, his hands in his pockets

dialogues.text: What's the Klan? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: A new TV series. The family's named Klutz. The oldest boy's name is Klu. The father dies. Klu is left with the Klan: five handsome, square-jawed, narrow- hipped brothers, two bosomy liquid-eyed sisters who sing country-western. It's like the Dukes of Hazzard. They drive around the South in a truck picking up trash. Avenging vacuum cleaners.

dialogues.text: They hate blacks.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: And Jews and Catholics and Quakers and Communists and punk rockers. They hate almost everybody.

dialogues.speaker: ERIC
dialogues.text: They kill blacks.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Why did you ask if you already knew?

dialogues.speaker: ERIC
dialogues.text: Are you gonna picket?

dialogues.text: I usually do.

dialogues.speaker: ERIC
dialogues.text: But you won't tomorrow, right? "Cause if you do, Daddy'll fire you and nothing is more important than your goddamn job. Right?

dialogues.speaker: TIGHT ON JACK
dialogues.text: stung, furious, silenced,

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack is stretched out on the daybed, hands behind his head, glaring at the ceiling, Eric is bacx on the slot machine. a ‘ (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: I never claimed to be Martin Luther King. Machine.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: (continuing) I'm not a world-class nigger. The machine hits the jackpot. Money spews into the cup, then onto the floor. Eric just looks at it awhile, then shoves his hands into his pockets, walks over to the day- bed, sits on the floor, leaning back against the daybed, playing the Rubic's Cube.

dialogues.speaker: ERIC
dialogues.text: When I was little I had this friend. We'd play at school and after school and weekends and he'd beat up people for me. And he'd spit at girls and let the air out of teacher's tires and flood the rest rooms.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Somebody worthy of you.

dialogues.speaker: ERIC
dialogues.text: I told Mama about him and she sent me to a shrink. He said I was too old to have imaginary friends. Jack takes the Rubic's Cube, adjusts it, hands it back.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Shrinks piss on the world.

dialogues.speaker: ERIC
dialogues.text: Grownups piss on the world.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Now wait a minute. You got my phone number. You can call me when you come back next year. I'm not imaginary, Eric.

dialogues.speaker: ERIC
dialogues.text: Yeah, you are. The Jack Brown I knew was a world-class nigger. Silence. The betrayal, the disappointment, the pain of it clear. Jack moves his hand ove~ and “ays it ou the boy's head. A mute apology.  174 175 105.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bates is pacing, snorting, furious, dressed in his elegant best. Fancy is in her minimums at the makeup table, doing a number on her face. The newspaper is on the edge of the table under her chiffon negligee.

dialogues.speaker: FANCY
dialogues.text: Do you like this new metallic eyeshadow, sugar, or does it look like Hookercity?

dialogues.speaker: BATES
dialogues.text: I'm losing my son.

dialogues.speaker: FANCY
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: BATES
dialogues.text: Jack Brown's taking my son away from me.

dialogues.speaker: FANCY
dialogues.text: Big deal.

dialogues.speaker: BATES
dialogues.text: Fancy.

dialogues.speaker: FANCY
dialogues.text: Well fire him, darling, if he bothers you.

dialogues.speaker: BATES
dialogues.text: I gave him a job on the paper. She sighs, prettily, uses the powder puff.

dialogues.speaker: FANCY
dialogues.text: Men are so mysterious.

dialogues.speaker: BATES
dialogues.text: It's the best way to bring him to heel. To shut him up. Fancy blinks her big eyes at him.

dialogues.speaker: FANCY
dialogues.text: Hank, your prostate. Bates mops his forehead with her negligee, notices the paper, wads it up, hurls it into the basket.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The back gardens of the house are terraced down the slope to the river. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Many different levels, each decorated with bunting. At the bottom, the Juilliard String Quartet is playing under a tent, with a dance floor. On another level a table full of information on the Klan's Youth Corps. Sign-ups and pledges. The Cadillacs and Mercedeses are simply parked in the pasture next to the gardens. The women hike up their chiffon, walk through the cockleburs and goat heads. The garden itself shimmers with elegance. Two hundred people Neisman's dressed. Liveried waiters. Buffet tables that are works of art. Everything in red, white and blue. The String Quartet breaks off abruptly, mid-Mozart. They swing into DIXIE.

dialogues.speaker: ON FRENCH DOORS
dialogues.text: at the top of the gardens, leading out of the house. The GOVERNOR comes out. He shakes hands with Bates. He is yet another good old boy with a ready smile, a beer belly and lethal slitty eyes. His WIFE, like Fancy, is very young, very decorative, very plastic.

dialogues.speaker: BATES
dialogues.text: Governor. I'm real glad you could make it.

dialogues.speaker: GOVERNOR
dialogues.text: What charity you raising money for today, Hank?

dialogues.speaker: BATES
dialogues.text: You remember Fancy? She wiggles up to him, thoroughly distracting him.

dialogues.speaker: GOVERNOR
dialogues.text: (kisses her) Sure do. I knew Fancy before you knew Fancy, Hank.

dialogues.speaker: BATES
dialogues.text: Now wait a second.

dialogues.speaker: GOVERNOR
dialogues.text: (laughing) When she was a little bitty thing in Amarillo. I loved the propellers on her bosoms. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: BATES
dialogues.text: You knew they were propellers, then? I'll be damned!

dialogues.speaker: GOVERNOR
dialogues.text: (laughs, pulls his wife forward) Now, Hank, I believe you've known Charlene just about forever. Bates kisses her.

dialogues.speaker: BATES
dialogues.text: Still on penicillin, sugar?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLENE
dialogues.text: For the peace of mind it brings me, darlin’.

dialogues.speaker: GOVERNOR
dialogues.text: Was it the City of Hope? Bates pulls an innocuous little man into the group, waves at the photographers.

dialogues.speaker: BATES
dialogues.text: Take a picture with the Governor, Sam. The Governor puts his arm around the man, smiles, flash. Bates pulls the man away. Moves close to the Governor.

dialogues.speaker: BATES
dialogues.text: (continuing) You know who that was, Governor?

dialogues.speaker: GOVERNOR
dialogues.text: Looked familiar. A friend of yours?

dialogues.speaker: BATES
dialogues.text: Grand wizard of the Klu Klux Klan. The Governor's face turns ashen.

dialogues.speaker: GOVERNOR
dialogues.text: This party is for him?

dialogues.speaker: BATES
dialogues.text: (smiling) Only way I could get him here. And get a picture of him with you. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: The Governor stares at Bates.

dialogues.speaker: GOVERNOR
dialogues.text: What do you want?

dialogues.speaker: BATES
dialogues.text: (smiling) I'm in a little difficulty with the Justice Department.

dialogues.speaker: AT BAR
dialogues.text: Barkley serves two drinks on a silver tray to a silver- haired gentleman.

dialogues.speaker: BARKLEY
dialogues.text: Bourbon and branch water, sir. A ROAR OF ENGINES splits the air. The silver-haired man jumps a foot. Barkley catches the drinks mid-air, replaces them in the silver tray.

dialogues.speaker: FULL
dialogues.text: Eric, dressed as the Roadrunner, riding the motorcycle, pursued by Jack dressed as Wily Coyote, driving the red Ferrari, his knees to his chin, hunched over the wheel. They streak through the party. The chiffoned ladies and the three-piece suited men are far too well bred to be astonished. They return to their bourbon and branch as if nothing is happening.

dialogues.speaker: ON BATES
dialogues.text: turning inward and lethal in his anger.

dialogues.speaker: ON GOVERNOR
dialogues.text: as Jack in the Ferrari zooms by. The Governor spills his drink jumping out of the way.

dialogues.speaker: ON JACK
dialogues.text: who grins back at him, the toothy asinine smile of Coyote  182 183 184 185 186 187 188 109.

dialogues.speaker: ON FANCY
dialogues.text: with a group of ladies at the pledge table as Eric, on the motorcycle, leaps over, misses, smashes onto the table, the brochures and checks and moneybox fly everywhe

dialogues.speaker: ERIC
dialogues.text: Beep, beep! Blasts off again.

dialogues.speaker: FANCY
dialogues.text: Eric, dammit!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: as the Ferrari plows through the mess, scattering the women as well as finishing off the fundraising.

dialogues.speaker: ON JACK AND ERIC
dialogues.text: grin at each other. Eric rears back on his motorcycle as Bates approaches, steaming.

dialogues.speaker: ERIC
dialogues.text: Beep, beep!

dialogues.speaker: FULL
dialogues.text: They dodge around Bates, first Eric, then Jack, despite his yelling at them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: as Jack chases Eric around the food tables, between the increasingly disturbed guests, jumping down terraces, bouncing down steps, across the dance floor, in and out of the String Quartet.

dialogues.speaker: BATES
dialogues.text: about to explode.

dialogues.speaker: FROM BATES' SHOULDER
dialogues.text: In the pasture, between the Mercedeses, the old VW bus pulls up. Blacks with picket signs disgorge.  189 190 197 192 193 110.

dialogues.speaker: ON BATES
dialogues.text: reacts, then collars Morehouse.

dialogues.speaker: BATES
dialogues.text: Dance.

dialogues.speaker: MOREHOUSE
dialogues.text: looks around, frazzled. Takes the first young honey he can reach, starts to dance.

dialogues.speaker: AT DANCE FLOOR
dialogues.text: Bates strides across, in a rage.

dialogues.speaker: BATES
dialogues.text: Play. They do so, in rhythm to Morehouse and the honey.

dialogues.speaker: AT BAR
dialogues.text: Bates barely pauses. Barkley hands him a drink.

dialogues.speaker: BATES
dialogues.text: Call the cops, Barkley.

dialogues.speaker: WITH BATES
dialogues.text: followed by Barkley. They nearly are upon Eric and Jack when they ZOOM off again. Bates turns on his heel and follows. As does Barkley.

dialogues.speaker: BARKLEY
dialogues.text: They're on their way, sir, did you want them to take all the blacks, sir?

dialogues.speaker: BATES
dialogues.text: Of course.

dialogues.speaker: BARKLEY
dialogues.text: Including Mister Brown, sir? I told them just the blacks with signs, sir, on the theory that it would be less obtrusive.

dialogues.speaker: BATES
dialogues.text: Right. You're quite right, Barkley.  194 195 ils

dialogues.speaker: ON PICKETERS
dialogues.text: Angela is organizing, encouraging, sweet and powerful.

dialogues.speaker: ANGELA
dialogues.text: Be sure they see your signs. We're not going to get rowdy. Jimmy, don't flip anyone a boner. He flips her one. They all laugh, move toward the gate.

dialogues.speaker: ANGELA
dialogues.text: (continuing) We're not here to kill anyone, just to embarrass, to disrupt, to focus attention --

dialogues.speaker: PARKING
dialogues.text: Jack brings the Ferrari to a skidding halt. Angela comes over to him.

dialogues.speaker: ANGELA
dialogues.text: Jesus, you look silly.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: So do you. She laughs.

dialogues.speaker: ANGELA
dialogues.text: Get your ass out of that, Jack! Grab a sign. The MOTORBIKE ROARS through the cars, Eric skids to a halt, lifts the laser gun, ZAPS him. Jack flies out of the Ferrari, does a terrific death scene as the picket team watches, in ‘patent disbelief.

dialogues.speaker: ERIC
dialogues.text: (yells) Angela! Hil In his death rattle, Jack draws a hidden pistol and FIRES at the boy. Eric looks around. Jack FIRES AGAIN. Then blows down the barrel of the gun. Eric does a magnifi- cently overacted death scene. Finally he too is quivering and silent.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: <b (to Eric) You're overacting, Squirrel. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: ANGELA
dialogues.text: Jack will you stop this foolishness! Bates is coming. Eric and Jack remount their vehicles.

dialogues.speaker: ANGELA
dialogues.text: (continuing) I won't be there when you get home. Eric zooms away.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: He looks at the boy, turns to Angela, grins his Coyote grin, REVS THE ENGINE, knees at his chin.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Yeah, you will. And takes off after the boy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eric on the motorbike, beep-beeping on a slalom course through the buffet tables. Then over the edge, down onto the next level.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: with his Coyote grin, pursuing, clipping one table after another, knocking each one over, like dominoes. Then working the next level.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The party is a shambles. SIRENS split the air. The police surround the protestors in the parking lot.

dialogues.speaker: ON ERIC
dialogues.text: leaning forward, gathering speed, grinning.

dialogues.speaker: FULL
dialogues.text: Eric blasts off a ramped jump, intending to land in the lake, undershooting it, landing instead on the tent over the String Quartet, which collapses into the lake.

dialogues.speaker: TIGHT
dialogues.text: The String Quartet scramble out of there.

dialogues.speaker: BARKLEY
dialogues.text: feels his pulse.

dialogues.speaker: FANCY
dialogues.text: stunned.

dialogues.speaker: FANCY
dialogues.text: I believe I am ready for the black experience.

dialogues.speaker: GUESTS
dialogues.text: head for their cars, for the house, to get out, civilized but quickly.

dialogues.speaker: ON BATES
dialogues.text: leaves a crowd of people, storms toward the garage, the ground shaking beneath his feet.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: leaps into the sinking mess in the river. Cables and canvas and mangled motorcycle, underneath which is the child.

dialogues.speaker: ANGELA'S VOICE
dialogues.text: (yells) Jack, dammit!

dialogues.speaker: ON ANGELA
dialogues.text: as she is escorted into the police van, handcuffed, looki back at Jack, betrayed.  209 210 211 212 213 214 114.

dialogues.speaker: ON JACK
dialogues.text: pulls the kid out of the mess of canvas and guy wires and motorcycle. Scoops him into his arms, sloshes toward the shore, carrying the boy.

dialogues.speaker: TIGHT
dialogues.text: Eric opens his eyes, manages a grin.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Beep, beep.

dialogues.speaker: ERIC
dialogues.text: Super genius wiley coyote. Hugs him, tight.

dialogues.speaker: ON GARAGE
dialogues.text: Hank Bates, his smile lethal behind the wheel, roars out of the garage in Fancy's pink Chrysler convertible, top d

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The wrecked gardens. The last of the guests, leaving. Jack carrying the boy up from the lake. The pink Chrysler hurtles off the top level of the terrace, Bates bent over the wheel, grinning, bearing down on them.

dialogues.speaker: JACK AND ERIC
dialogues.text: stunned.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Holy Toledo. Eric leaps out of Jack's arms, runs for the Ferrari.

dialogues.speaker: AT FERRARI
dialogues.text: Eric jumps in at the controls.

dialogues.speaker: HURRY
dialogues.text: Jack lifts his hands in surrender tow*rd the oncoming Bat (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Better Red then dead. Eric grabs the wet Coyote tail and yanks. Jack falls into the passenger seat, Eric guns it. The Ferrari spins out of there, leaving deep tracks in the turf, scorching the bushes with its exhaust.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: as the Chrysler pursues the Ferrari, outmaneuvering it, gaining on it. Bates hunched over the wheel, grinning.

dialogues.speaker: TIGHT ON JACK
dialogues.text: He turns, alarmed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bates is breathing down their tailpipe.

dialogues.speaker: FULL
dialogues.text: At the last possible second, where the obvious way is to the right, Eric turns left, yanking the Ferrari in a stee skid, then blasting out of the garden, disappearing aroun the corner of the house.

dialogues.speaker: ON BATES
dialogues.text: who cannot react in time, ends up stalling under a lush fushia bush. Swatting the lovely flowers out of his face as he starts the car up again, backs it out, shoves it again in gear.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. BREAKS
dialogues.text: As Eric and Jack bounce over one particularly bad hump, Jack flies out of the car entirely, hanging onto the roll bar with one hand. Eric never slows down. Jack pulls himself back into the car more out of the feaz of what will happen to him if he 1+t< go, -hai bravery.  oN 221 222 223 224 225 226 227 116.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Chrysler flies over the ridge in front of them, beari down on them. At the last possible second, Eric skids, stripping the paint off both cars, scaring the shit out of Jack.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: What're you trying to do, kill the kid?!

dialogues.speaker: BATES
dialogues.text: You! I'm trying to kill youl!

dialogues.speaker: TIGHT ON JACK
dialogues.text: sinks into his seat.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Oh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Ferrari disappears into the woods near the fishing pond. Moment, then the Chrysler follows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They hide the Ferrari, more or less, under some brush, duck behind a tree. The sound of the Chrysler approaching

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: is about to sneeze. Eric covers his mouth, his nose, punches him in the stomach. Jack sneezes anyway.

dialogues.speaker: ON BATES
dialogues.text: hearing the sneeze, he jerks the steering wheel in that direction. It comes off in his hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Chrysler without a steering wheel, hits a stump and takes to the air, end over end, then landing, Bates first in the pond. The splash displaces most of the water. ra  o~ 228 229 230 231 232 117.

dialogues.speaker: WITH JACK AND ERIC
dialogues.text: who run to the edge as man and car disappear under the surface. Bubbles.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: How deep is it?

dialogues.speaker: ERIC
dialogues.text: (grins) Plenty. Jack looks outraged at the boy, then dives in. Badly. The Coyote costume splaying out behind him, the tail the last to go under.

dialogues.speaker: ON ERIC
dialogues.text: astonished. -

dialogues.speaker: ON POND
dialogues.text: as Jack hauls Bates out of the pond, Bates is covered wit mud and virtually unconscious. Jack is gasping for breath

dialogues.speaker: EDGE
dialogues.text: Jack dumps the whale of a man on dry land. Bates is coughing, and gasping. Jack wrings out his tail. Eric is stiff with anger.

dialogues.speaker: ERIC
dialogues.text: Why'd you do that? Jack looks at Bates, then at Eric.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: (laughs) I don't know. Jack throws him back. Bates comes to the surface, sputtering and furious.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack is packing. Eric is nowhere to be seen. The door BURSTS open, Bates is there, a bottle in one hand, a glas in the other, drunk.

dialogues.speaker: BATES
dialogues.text: Why the hell do you call it the NAACP if you don't want to be called 'colored people'? If you wanna be called 'black' why don't you call it the NAAB? (stumbles toward Jack, through a jungle of toys) That wouldn't be right either. You're not black. You're the color of dried manure. He chortles, lifts his chin, looks at Jack blearily, challengingly. Jack continues to pack.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Or old whiskey. Bates blinks. He leans on a rocking horse to consider that. It rocks away from him. He falls -- not spilling a drop from either his glass or the bottle. He struggles up, glares at the horse, decides to get on, cannot without hands. Falls over the other side. Jack picks him up.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: (continuing) Want me to call Barkley, Mr. Bates? You want to go back to your room?

dialogues.speaker: BATES
dialogues.text: Your women spend a fortune on straightening their hair. Our women a fortune on frizzes. Yours bleach their skin. Ours tan theirs. I wanna be young, you don't want to be called 'Boy." I spend a mint buying that kid everything his heart desires and he turns on me. (leans against Jack, wipes his eyes on Jack's shirt, then blows his nose) Nothing makes sense, Jack. Jack wipes his shirt off on Bates.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: So let's share a joint. Bates pulls himself shakily together. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: BATES
dialogues.text: An apartment? With you? Good God, why? Jack laughs steers him to the daybed where Bates collapse knocking the suitcase to the floor.

dialogues.speaker: BATES
dialogues.text: (continuing) Sorry.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: No sweat. He begins to repack. Bates pours two glasses, hands Jack one.

dialogues.speaker: BATES
dialogues.text: Drink with me. Jack smiles, lifts his glass.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: To the mysteries of life. I can't stand you. And I'd give my left ball to be you. Bates smiles, drinks.

dialogues.speaker: BATES
dialogues.text: You got the love of my son. I'd give my left ball for that.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: (shrugs) Keep him here. Spend some time with him. Make time to spend with him,

dialogues.speaker: BATES
dialogues.text: You read that paper. He thinks I'm some kind of a monster.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Well aren't you? Bates drinks.

dialogues.speaker: BATES
dialogues.text: I hired Ruby Dee back. I hadn't realized.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Bullshit.

dialogues.speaker: BATES
dialogues.text: I did. And Geffran. Jack looks at him, amazed, pours the man another drink.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: You got the balls to give a party for the goddam Klu Klux Klan so as to get leverage with the Governor and you're scared of your own son? Come on, Mr. Bates, get your act together.

dialogues.speaker: BATES
dialogues.text: It's together. I just forgot where I left it. Jack rolls his eyes at the ceiling, returns to packing. Bates shakes with amusement, pours two more drinks, splashing a good deal into the suitcase.

dialogues.speaker: BATES
dialogues.text: (continuing) You know, you're all right. For a colored boy.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: You're all right yourself. For a honkey bastard. Laughing, they raise their glasses to each other.

dialogues.speaker: BATES
dialogues.text: By the way. You're fired.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: No shit. And Dolly Parton sleeps on her back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack, on his bike, comes around the corner, suitcase strapped on the back, heading down the driveway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The boy is sitting in the darkness, in the windowseat, watching him go.  235 236 237 238 121.

dialogues.speaker: JACK'S SHOULDER
dialogues.text: Jack sees the boy in the window, waves. The boy waves back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack pedals around the corner into the racket of street life, MUSIC and YELLING and BOTTLES BREAKING.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack pulls the bike with the suitcase on it, onto the porch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack wheels his bike in. And stops. Angela is finishing her packing. The place is denuded. What she has not been able to pack she has stuffed in a garbage pail in the middle of the room.. Rolling up the Monet, she glares at Jack.

dialogues.speaker: ANGELA
dialogues.text: Bates' toy. I wouldn't've believed it if I hadn't've seen it.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: The boy needed a friend, Angela.

dialogues.speaker: ANGELA
dialogues.text: And it didn't matter that I needed you? Racially, politically and personally. I needed you.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Not like he did.

dialogues.speaker: ANGELA
dialogues.text: It was the most negative kind of a statement you could make, Jack, you completely destroyed my eredibility in the black leadership around here. But you don't care. You were having fun, you --

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: (interrupting) Symington said the trouble with the clowns running this country was that they spent so much time listening to the roll of drums, they couldn't hear the cry of a hild. ent (CONTINUED)  238 239 240 241 242 121A.

dialogues.speaker: ANGELA
dialogues.text: He didn't mean a child like that, dumbass! A rich, arrogant, spoiled, vicious --

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: He's still a child, Angie.

dialogues.speaker: ANGELA
dialogues.text: Then why are you here? If you're joined at the hip.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: I got fired. She stares at him, stunned.

dialogues.speaker: ANGELA
dialogues.text: And you still don't get it? He's the enemy, Jack. She lifts her bags, heads for the door.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Angela. I love you. She continues toward the door.

dialogues.speaker: ANGELA
dialogues.text: Happy trails, Uncle Tom. And exits.

dialogues.speaker: TIGHT ON JACK
dialogues.text: sinks against the wall, defeated, fighting it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Chrysler Limousine slides under the sign... Bates International Airport... ahead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eric, his face swollen from crying, wearing his military school uniform, is scrunched in the corner of the back seat. Bates, smiling, is sitting calmly beside him.

dialogues.speaker: BATES
dialogues.text: Eric, I want you to understand something. (MORE) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Sine a. 122.

dialogues.speaker: BATES, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Every oil well I drill, every cable system I buy, every store I open, is for you. (smiles) You personally will control South Central Louisiana when you grow up.

dialogues.speaker: ERIC
dialogues.text: Big deal.

dialogues.speaker: BATES
dialogues.text: It is a big deal.

dialogues.speaker: ERIC
dialogues.text: Jack says life's about people, not about power.

dialogues.speaker: BATES
dialogues.text: I'm not interested in what Jack says.

dialogues.speaker: ERIC
dialogues.text: Jack says it's about being together and being friends.

dialogues.speaker: BATES
dialogues.text: Did you hear what I said, Eric?

dialogues.speaker: ERIC
dialogues.text: Jack says you don't have any friends. Jack says you know two kinds of people. Ones that owe you and ones you owe.

dialogues.speaker: BATES
dialogues.text: I don't want to lose my temper.

dialogues.speaker: ERIC
dialogues.text: Jack says all you love is playing pool and making deals and politics and whiskey.

dialogues.speaker: BATES
dialogues.text: Is that a crime? Eric glares out the window, eyes swimming.

dialogues.speaker: ERIC
dialogues.text: Well. You have a kid. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: BATES
dialogues.text: What about Africa this summer. There's no need for you to go to camp again. We could go to Africa. Just the two of us. Photographing animals. You're good at photography. Silence.

dialogues.speaker: ERIC
dialogues.text: I hate you. Silence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The limo parks near a Lear with the steps down. The PILOT comes over. Barkley opens the trunk, takes out the boy's small suitcase.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: as the Pilot shakes hands with Bates.

dialogues.speaker: PILOT
dialogues.text: Mr. Bates. The storm seems to be moving Southwest. We'll pass well to the east without a problem. (grins at Eric) Well, sport, ready for school?

dialogues.speaker: ERIC
dialogues.text: turns on his heel and runs.

dialogues.speaker: FULL
dialogues.text: The boy sprints toward the main terminal, cutting across runways. The three men look after him in confusion, then start after him, on foot, get halfway across the tarmak before they realize they'll never catch him, turn and run back to the car and the plane.

dialogues.speaker: ERIC
dialogues.text: running and running and running. His breath coming harder, tossing a lock behind him, then turning on the speed, running toward the main terminal.   248 249 250 251 252 124.

dialogues.speaker: LIMO
dialogues.text: as it skids around in a circle, then screams out of the private airfield.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The limo dodges and darts in and out of the clogged traff Way ahead, the boy gets in the back of a cab and slams the door. The cab pulls into the traffic.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown

dialogues.text: Mr. Brown. Hank Bates, here. The boy, uh, Eric has run away. I suppose he's coming to you. I would appreciate it if you would keep him there for me. I'll be there in a minute.

dialogues.text: The cab pulls up. Jack, bareheaded, is pacing back and forth in front of the building, angry. The boy gets out.

dialogues.speaker: ERIC
dialogues.text: Can you pay him? TI don't have any money. Jack leans into the cab, pays, then turns to the boy in a fury.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: "Run away'? What's this shit about ‘running away'?

dialogues.text: I want to stay with you. Jack looks at him in dismay. Around the corner wheels the limo.

dialogues.text: No! Jack pulls the boy out from where he is hiding behind him He drags him, kicking and screaming to the car, during:

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: He's your father, you gotta live with that, you gotta deal with that, you gotta quit hiding behind me! Opens the car door, throws him in.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: (cont inuing) I'm sick of the Bateses, father and son. Sick of you. You're nothing but trouble. I don't want to see either one of you ever again! (to Bates) Understand? (to Eric) Understand?! Bates shakes his hand.

dialogues.text: You see. (beat) You just thought he was your friend. (beat) I'm the one who's really your friend. The limo rolls to a stop at a stop sign. Eric grabs the handle of the door, yanks it open, jiumps out.  254

dialogues.speaker: ERIC
dialogues.text: is nearly hit as a lowrider skids around the corner. Eric dodges it, onto the sidewalk, tumbling around people, vaulting over garbage cans, crashing through, sprinting through.

dialogues.speaker: FULL
dialogues.text: As Eric barrels down the street toward Jack, Bates steps out of the car. (yells, meaning it) No! Eric skids to a stop.

dialogues.speaker: TIGHT ON ERIC
dialogues.text: his face streaked with tears and anger and confusion. He looks back to his father.

dialogues.speaker: BATES
dialogues.text: stops in his tracks, a half a block away.

dialogues.speaker: BATES
dialogues.text: I love you!

dialogues.speaker: FULL
dialogues.text: The boy looks back and forth, one to the other, then finally screams at his father.

dialogues.speaker: ERIC
dialogues.text: Is it true? That I'll have the stores and the oil and the TV stations and everything?

dialogues.text: Then. Drop. Your. Pants. Daddy. High noon city. Bates profoundly embarrassed, but re- fusing to look the liar in front of his kid, unbuckles his pants and drops them. He wears boxer shorts, printed with the Lacoste alligator.

dialogues.text: The three of them, arms around each other's waists, head for the limo, taking mincing little steps, their pants around their ankles, laughing.
